summary: [server] - ServletContextAdaptor. deleteOnExit will not work
description: [server] - ServletContextAdaptor. deleteOnExit will not work [reply] Description Pascal Rapicault 2006-09-21 09:52:46 EDT ServletContextAdaptor. deleteOnExit call will do nothing if the folder is not empty. In addtion this only gets cleaned up when the VM shutsdown which is too late.  We need to propagate the destroy lifecycle to this and be carefull to ref count the usage of http context.  [reply] Comment 1 Simon Kaegi 2006-09-30 01:02:55 EDT All Context Attributes and the "javax.servlet.context.tempdir" associated with an HttpContext are now reference counted and when unreferenced are cleaned up. In addition, the ProxyContext will cleanup any stragglers that couldn't otherwise be deleted during its initialization and termination. Fixed in HEAD.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: Windows Event Log rules adapters may generate incorrect creationTime values
description: Windows Event Log rules adapters may generate incorrect creationTime values [reply] Description Hari H Krishna 2006-09-21 09:53:18 EDT https://cs.opensource.ibm.com/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=10654  Steps to Reproduce: 1. Import a WAS activity log (text version) with the rules-based adapter. 2. Notice that some of the creationTime values do not match the timestamps in the corresponding records in the log file.  This problem was introduced in AC 4.2 when the substitution rule for creation time was changed to use the @TIMEZONE and timeFormat string options.  TPTP adapter to be modified 1. Windows Security 2. Windows Application 3. Windows System  [reply] Comment 1 Hari H Krishna 2006-09-21 10:06:21 EDT As per discussion with Uliyana and Eric canging the severity to critical  [reply] Comment 2 Dave Smith 2006-09-21 17:50:57 EDT While there is a problem parsing some log files with a rules adapter that uses a timeFormat string to parse a timestamp that includes fractional seconds, it does not affect the Windows Event log adapters.  This is because the Windows Event logs do not include a fractional second value but the EventLogReader program that converts the binary event log into a text file pads the timestamp with a fractional second value of 6 zeros (eg. CreationTime: 10/24/2005 14:25:05.000000;).  The fractional seconds are only an issue if they are non-zero.  In the Windows Event log case I believe they will always be zero.  I have never encountered one where it was non zero.  Therefore, I will downgrade the severity to normal since the problem has never been encountered with Windows Event Logs.  However, I'll target this to 4.3 to fix the creationTime rule to truncate the fractional seconds to 3 digits in case the event logs change in the future to generate timestamps with longer fractional seconds. This downgrading has been negotiated with Eric Labadie who represents the consuming product who opened this bugzilla.  [reply] Comment 3 Dave Smith 2006-10-24 17:23:02 EDT Deferring to 4.4 as it is not a stop ship issue and cannot be contained in 4.3.  [reply] Comment 4 Dave Smith 2007-01-17 23:40:30 EST Added sizing.  [reply] Comment 5 Dave Smith 2007-02-06 02:15:02 EST Targetting to fix in i3 and increasing priority to indicate it is planned for 4.4.  [reply] Comment 6 Dave Smith 2007-02-06 17:43:15 EST Changing to a more appropriate component.  The adapter files are in the Monitor.Analysis component.  [reply] Comment 7 Dave Smith 2007-04-25 15:20:38 EDT Committed fix to TPTP Head CVS.  The fix was to change the match pattern in the creationTime rule from  "(\d{2}/\d{2}/\d{4}\s\d{2}:\d{2}:\d{2}\.\d{6})"  to  "(\d{2}/\d{2}/\d{4}\s\d{2}:\d{2}:\d{2}\.\d{3})\d{3}"  in all Windows event log adapter files.  [reply] Comment 8 Paul Slauenwhite 2009-06-30 13:15:28 EDT As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [server] [comments] Need to comment the usage of getResourcePaths
description: [server] [comments] Need to comment the usage of getResourcePaths [reply] Description Pascal Rapicault 2006-09-21 10:16:26 EDT ServletContextAdaptor makes use of reflection to call getResourcePaths. This needs to be documented.  [reply] Comment 1 Simon Kaegi 2006-09-22 00:47:43 EDT [Comment Added] This method was added in the Servlet 2.3 API however the OSGi HttpService currently does not provide support for this method in the HttpContext interface. To support "getResourcePaths(...) this implementation uses reflection to check for and then call the associated HttpContext.getResourcePaths(...) method opportunistically. Null is returned if the method is not present or fails.  -- As this behaviour is not in the spec and implementation note needs to be added to the FAQ.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [server] [doc] "servlet-name" needs to be documented
description: [server] [doc] "servlet-name" needs to be documented [reply] Description Pascal Rapicault 2006-09-21 10:19:21 EDT In ServletConfigImpl "servlet-name" should be a documented.  [reply] Comment 1 Pascal Rapicault 2006-09-21 13:52:04 EDT Do we need to make this constant available on an interface?  [reply] Comment 2 Simon Kaegi 2006-09-21 23:39:36 EDT "servlet-name" comes from the webapp deployment descriptor but as with many named constants does not appear in the API itself. It doesn't really make sense to put in an implementation as the user would likely only depend on the HttpService and Servlet API.  So... in addition to javadoc I think we look to incorporate this (and a few others) as implementation notes in the FAQ.  [reply] Comment 3 Simon Kaegi 2006-09-22 00:49:22 EDT [Comment Added] The OSGi Http Service does not specify a way to set a servlet name at the API level. This implementation will try to use the value of the "servlet-name" initial parameter if available.  -- Also needs to be added to the FAQ  [reply] Comment 4 Simon Kaegi 2006-09-22 12:24:15 EDT Forgot to mark this fixed  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

We're managing the lifecycle of the framework directly in this context so it should be startup/shutdown.    [reply] Comment 2 Simon Kaegi 2006-09-29 13:52:55 EDT Done. Fixed in HEAD. summary: [server] generate the extension bundle on startup
description: [server] generate the extension bundle on startup [reply] Description Pascal Rapicault 2006-09-21 11:31:09 EDT Because the extension bundle is speicfic to each container it could be generated on startup of the servletbridge.jar.  [reply] Comment 1 Simon Kaegi 2006-09-29 13:31:34 EDT I've added support for generating the servletbridge's extension bundle at runtime on the HEAD. In particular, exporting the correct version of the Servlet API has been confusing and this change will simplify configuration. By default the Servlet API and o.e.e.servletbridge are exported. Additional exports may be added by using the "extendedFrameworkExport" ServletConfig init-param in web.xml.  Note: This bundle is only generated if not already present in the plugins directory. This preserves existing usage (and provide an override mechanism) where a pre-created extensionbundle can be deployed along with all other bundles in WEB-INF/eclipse/plugins.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [server] Design a filtering mechanism to decide against which service instance a servlet is registered
description: [server] Design a filtering mechanism to decide against which service instance a servlet is registered [reply] Description Pascal Rapicault 2006-09-21 11:41:20 EDT The current implementation of http.registry registers all servlete and resources against all the sercies available. We need a way to filter that. Two solutions: 1) an ldap filter in the xml, but this will limit the reusability of the bundle 2) getting the values from the config admin service  [reply] Comment 1 Simon Kaegi 2006-10-10 17:06:11 EDT As an initial step I like your first suggestion; adding an LDAP service registration filter to the xml. It's fairly straight-forward and handles the use-case although admittedly at a cost in terms of reusability. By default if no filter is specified all servlets, resources, and httpcontexts will continue to be associated with all services.  I'd like to track the runtime config approach in a separate bug as it's more involved and I'm less sure on the timing.  [reply] Comment 2 Jeff McAffer 2006-10-10 17:32:40 EDT I can't help but feel this is a bad direction.  It violates the producer/consumer separation and encourages "bad" behaviour.  Config admin is one way. Something akin to the capabilities mechanism where a third party describes the set of contributions that should be linked into a particular server is another (similar) approach.  My hesitation here is that we will introduce something that basically we will then tell people to not use.  [reply] Comment 3 Simon Kaegi 2006-10-10 18:09:37 EDT Alright. I'll buy that we should wait on this as there isn't really a pressing need at the moment as its quite rare to run more than one HttpService in a single VM.  I understand the producer/consumer concern and it's definitely legitimate. I'm relatively comfortable with a "filter" attribute however as I think that eventually we could use it at runtime. I'm hoping we can dynamically alter an extension and then receive and respond to a "changed" event. We don't have this capability currently so I'll accept that we shouldn't tie ourselves to the static approach. [Untargetting until we have a more concrete approach.]  [reply] Comment 4 Simon Kaegi 2006-10-25 21:49:37 EDT I think that the recent plugin "customization" worked talk about on the dev list is relevant to this bug report. ...offering to help test here.  [reply] Comment 5 Pascal Rapicault 2006-10-26 08:41:52 EDT I disagree. This mechanism should not be used as an excuse for sloppy design, or part of a solution for customizability. This xml processing mechanism should be used for backward compatibility issues and "bad plugins" in the context of a product. Therefore I would not expect the eclipse platform to ship with such files or recommend its usage.  Also there are no guarantee that this mechanism will make it into eclipse  [reply] Comment 6 Simon Kaegi 2007-03-16 17:57:35 EDT I agree that the customization should only be used to deal with problem situations.  The approach we're considering is to add a <serviceSelector/> element (to the servlets and resources extensions) that will have two modes of operation. The first takes an ldap "filter" as an attribute and uses it to filter which Http Service to register agains. The second approach uses a "class" attribute that will cause instantiation of a Filter class capable of arbitrary filtering -- one example being to create a filter from Config Admin.  To try and address re-usability we're adding the capability to define your extensions in a separate plugin from your resources. See bug 163586  [reply] Comment 7 Simon Kaegi 2007-03-17 02:33:03 EDT fixed in HEAD  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [server] Need a factory to create http server on various ports
description: [server] Need a factory to create http server on various ports [reply] Description Pascal Rapicault 2006-09-21 11:57:10 EDT With the current implementation of the jetty bridge, it is not possible to create multiple servers on different ports.  [reply] Comment 1 Simon Archer 2006-09-30 16:02:26 EDT You might want to consider doing this with OSGi's Managed Service Factory specification, which allows configurations to be created using Configuration Admin.  In my experience it works pretty well.  [reply] Comment 2 Simon Kaegi 2006-09-30 20:16:59 EDT That's the plan... Of course we'd better look at graduating the config admin implementation first.  [reply] Comment 3 Simon Archer 2006-09-30 21:55:25 EDT It would be worth considering how users of the server will be expected to configure a registered Managed Service Factory, and potentially a Managed Service.  While they could certainly write code to provision the server via Configuration Admin, it might also be useful to provide a web interface.  Of course this might open up a more general discussion of how to dynamically provision the server.  Restarting and/or rebuilding the WAR for such an administrative task is probably not desirable.  [reply] Comment 4 Simon Kaegi 2006-12-20 02:55:40 EST Created attachment 55940 [details] Factory support via Config Admin  Here's a patch that adds factory support via Config Admin to allow the controlled creation of Http Services. The Config Admin implementation is still not graduated however this patch can still be tested with the version in the incubator. I'm still looking into how to best document the parameters with using the metatype spec being the leading candidate. For now you can take a look at the code and the propeties in HttpServerManager. I'll also post a very simple test bundle. I'll keep testing however even without Config Admin graduated I'll look to add these changes to the depot shortly. summary: [mac] process lists are always empty with Mac OS X target
description: [mac] process lists are always empty with Mac OS X target [reply] Description David Dykstal 2006-09-22 09:00:59 EDT Open any filter under the processes subsystem supported by dstore. The process list always shows up as empty. The miner is probably not returning the list from the target system (also Mac OS X) properly since its a BSD based system.  [reply] Comment 1 David Dykstal 2006-11-02 10:17:29 EST *** Bug 162997 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***  [reply] Comment 2 David Dykstal 2006-11-08 17:20:11 EST The "ps" command used to fetch the list of processes was not working for Mac OS X which apparently has a finicky implementation. Single quotes cannot be used to contain the keywords for the -o parameter. Commas must be used instead to delimit the individual keywords. The -A parameter cannot be used since Runtime#exec() does not return. -a works, but it does not show "non-terminal" processes, i.e. those on those started with the "open" command or from the Finder. We will live with this limitation for the time being.  [reply] Comment 3 David Dykstal 2006-11-09 17:30:26 EST Verified.  -----------Enter bugs above this line----------- RSE 1.0 Testing Verification of fixes for I20061109 installation : Eclipse M20060629-1905 platform-3.2.1 RSE install  : RSE SDK I20061109 java.runtime : Sun VM 1.5 os.name:     : Mac OS X 10.4.8 ------------------------------------------------ systemtype   : Unix-Dstore targetos     : Mac OS X targetvm     : Sun VM 1.5 --------------------------------------  [reply] Comment 4 Martin Oberhuber 2006-11-23 06:53:01 EST Closing.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: Filter gets created into wrong filter pool
description: Filter gets created into wrong filter pool [reply] Description David Dykstal 2006-09-22 10:01:42 EDT Show pools. Create filter into a custom pool. The filter appears to end up in the "default private" pool.  [reply] Comment 1 David Dykstal 2006-12-12 10:11:54 EST This appears to happen only the first time an attempt is made to add a filter to the pool. Subsequent attempts work correctly.  The new filter wizard also complains if you attempt to name the filter with the same name as one that exists in the default filter pool. This indicates that the wrong filter pool is being fed into the process on the first attempt.  [reply] Comment 2 David Dykstal 2006-12-12 10:29:56 EST It also appears that the pool the filter ends up in is not the "default private" pool, but the last pool used.  [reply] Comment 3 David Dykstal 2006-12-12 14:40:03 EST Every SystemBaseDialogAction has an input value that can override its input. In this case the value from the last execution of this action was overriding the selected filter pool. That value is now erased when the selected filter pool is set for the action.  [reply] Comment 4 Javier Montalvo Or┣s 2006-12-13 13:18:25 EST Creating a new pool and then a new filter in the new pool successfuly shows the new filter in the new pool.  [reply] Comment 5 David Dykstal 2007-05-25 23:32:08 EDT closing previously verified bug reports  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: "Enter Password" window generates PDE runtime errors
description: "Enter Password" window generates PDE runtime errors [reply] Description Javier Montalvo Or┣s 2006-09-22 10:55:02 EDT When being prompted for a password (ex. when connecting to an FTP server), every time the "Password" field is empty, a PDE runtime error with message "RSEG1035E" is created.  This error should be raised in a way that is not persisted by the Eclipse Error Log, for example, displaying a WizardPage in the "Enter Password" window and showing the error with the WizardPage setErrorMessage() method.  This bug is similar to the one described by my note in 149282  [reply] Comment 1 Martin Oberhuber 2006-09-22 10:59:07 EDT Kushal I think this is yours  [reply] Comment 2 David Dykstal 2006-09-22 11:26:57 EDT Actually, this one is mine.  [reply] Comment 3 David Dykstal 2006-09-22 11:31:15 EDT This is by design. All error messages are logged when the logging level is set to "error". The message you are seeing in the log is the "Enter Password" message.  I think there should be one more logging level added for logging only errors that are not dialog validation errors like this and that this new logging level be made the default. This would prevent validation errors from showing up in the log.  All validation errors are displayed (and logged) using the SystemMessageLine class so testing the logging of messages there would be fairly straightforward.  [reply] Comment 4 Javier Montalvo Or┣s 2006-09-22 12:38:26 EDT (In reply to comment #3) > This is by design. All error messages are logged when the logging level is set > to "error". The message you are seeing in the log is the "Enter Password" > message. > > I think there should be one more logging level added for logging only errors > that are not dialog validation errors like this and that this new logging level > be made the default. This would prevent validation errors from showing up in > the log. > > All validation errors are displayed (and logged) using the SystemMessageLine > class so testing the logging of messages there would be fairly straightforward. >  Although is is a minor issue, having those errors in the error log could be seen as real errors by the end user, and also don't make real errors easily visible.  As you said, providing a new logging level not logging validation errors could be a solution.  [reply] Comment 5 David Dykstal 2006-09-22 17:04:57 EDT *** Bug 158327 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***  [reply] Comment 6 David Dykstal 2006-09-22 17:27:46 EDT An API call has been added to RSEUIPlugin to set and retrieve a setting for logging. The default is to not log these messages.  [reply] Comment 7 Martin Oberhuber 2006-09-25 10:00:18 EDT Setting Target Milestone 1.0 RC1 since this has been fixed just after 1.0M5. summary: Cascading Parameter Group Causes Javascript Error in IE
description: Cascading Parameter Group Causes Javascript Error in IE [reply] Description Gary Lee 2006-09-27 17:33:26 EDT We have a report with a cascading report parameter group   The group has three parameters that a displayed with combo boxes.  When using IE, if the user chooses an item in the first combo box and then generates the report without selecting an  value for the 2nd or 3rd parameter a javascript error occurs.  The error was caused by the following line in the collect_parameter : function( )  var temp = oSEC[0].options[oSEC[0].selectedIndex].text;  The problem is caused by oSEC[0].selectedIndex having a value of -1 which is an invalid index.  On Firefox, this selectedIndex value is zero when an item is not selected.  As a temporary fix, we have added the following code to insure the index is zero instead of -1.  if (oSEC[0].selectedIndex == -1) { oSEC[0].selectedIndex = 0; }  [reply] Comment 1 Jerry Cheng 2006-09-27 22:06:52 EDT Has fixed in 2.2.0. Please check it.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: Keeping an old builder configuration causes strange UI behaviour
description: Keeping an old builder configuration causes strange UI behaviour [reply] Description Steve Young 2006-09-28 12:48:05 EDT If an old AspectJ project is opened, the user is presented with a dialog, informing them that the project's builder is out of date, that a new builder will be added to the project, and asking whether the user wants to keep the old builder as well.  This works, in that the two builder configs exist in the .project file.  However, on the Builder page of the project's properties page, both builders are listed with the same name, so the user has to guess which one is old and which new.  In addition, deselecting the newer builder is possible, but on application of this choice, the same dialog appears, and the new builder conifg is added to the project again (and selected).  There are now three builders defined in the .project file and thus the properties page.  If multiple builders are allowed to be maintained then:  1. they should be named/versioned in the properties page 2. it should not be possible to deselect the new builder (since it is clearly essential)  [reply] Comment 1 Matt Chapman 2006-10-02 10:33:48 EDT The option to keep the old builder was to aid transition to the new builder by allowing projects to be shared between versions of AJDT with each builders. But the last release with the old builder was AJDT 1.1.12 over two years ago, so this level of compatibility is no longer required. The easiest fix here is therefore to remove the option to keep the old builder. The transition to the new builder will now happen automatically without prompting the user.  [reply] Comment 2 Matt Chapman 2006-10-03 04:35:10 EDT Now fixed in: 1.4.1.200610021418 for Eclipse 3.2 (build.210) 1.5.0.200610021411 for Eclipse 3.3M2 (build.47)  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [Viewers] multiple dispose listeners for elements in VIRTUAL tree viewer
description: [Viewers] multiple dispose listeners for elements in VIRTUAL tree viewer [reply] Description Darin Wright 2006-09-28 16:02:00 EDT 3.3  Each time an element is mapped in a VIRTUAL tree viewer, a dispose listener is hooked to its item to properly unmap it. However, elements are mapped to the same item more than once (each time it is updated via doUpdateItem(Widget widget, Object element, boolean fullMap)).  This results in many dispose listeners for each element to unmap it, which is a potential performance issue.  The debugger subclasses the tree viewer and updates (clears) filtered children when an element is unmapped. It ends up doing the operation many times (once for each dispose callback), instead of once.  [reply] Comment 1 Thomas Schindl 2006-09-29 04:24:47 EDT Created attachment 51148 [details] Stop adding dispose-listeners when TreeItem is reused  This patch tries to get rid of the problem described by setting a flag to remember if the dispose listener is already added to the item. I didn't had an idea how to write a TestCase for this. The current TestSuite lacks a test for Virtual-Viewers to check appropriate unmapping I think.  [reply] Comment 2 Boris Bokowski 2006-10-11 09:55:10 EDT Released >20061011.  [reply] Comment 3 Boris Bokowski 2006-11-01 11:03:21 EST Verified using I20061031-0656.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [Project Sets] Problems importing team project set

If you manually edit all the psf files and replace "extssh" with "pserver" it works.  Can we catch this error situation and prompt the user for which repository connection they would like to use to perform the checkout? In essence, this would be very similar to the first two pages of the checkout wizard. To make the dialog show up you will need to import a project set which has different connection method that one from your Repositories list (host and repository path should be the same).  The dialog doesn't change the way project set importing takes place. There are just some system.outs to show a selection one have made after the dialog is closed.  Moreover, after yesterday's manual tests I bumped into another alternative repository selection dialog which already exist in Eclipse. I though I can combine these two and reuse that code. Screenshots will follow.  There is also Mylar's Context attached.  [reply] Comment 9 Tomasz Zarna 2007-03-21 09:45:21 EDT Created attachment 61540 [details] mylar/context/zip  [reply] Comment 10 Tomasz Zarna 2007-03-21 09:47:51 EDT Created attachment 61541 [details] The dialog from CVS properties  This is the dialog I mentioned in comment 8. After clicking on [...] button on my dialog "Select a Repository" dialog shows up, when selection is made, dialog is closed. Selected repository is then displayed in the second column, next to the repository from a project set.  [reply] Comment 12 Michael Valenta 2007-03-21 10:07:56 EDT From the screen shots, the what you have looks good but we need to add the ability to create a new repository location as well. I tried the patch and my first task was to load a project set into a new workspace. In this scenario, I would still expect to be prompted to create an alternate repository location (i.e. I still may need to convert an extssh to a pserver or vica versa and it would also be helpful if I could provide a user name that would become a fixed part of the repository location.  On the technical side of things, I think we can get away with adding a method to the IUserAuthenticator interface for prompting which saves us from needing to define another extension point.  [reply] Comment 13 Tomasz Zarna 2007-03-23 08:45:25 EDT Created attachment 61808 [details] Advanced configuration of an alternative repository  Michael, I hope this screen shot is closer to your vision of the alternative repository configuration. Let me quickly describe it. First of all, the "Import Project Set" dialog from the screen shot will be displayed every time user imports a project sets. This can be changed by ticking a checkbox there. The second dialog pops up when user clicks [...] button. I belive that three radio buttons there are self-explanatory. Worth mentioning is the fact that fields from "Configure new repository" will be populated with values from "CVS Repository from the change set" or "'Compatible' repository" respectively. I was also thinking about adding a button to clear all these fields. Doesn't the new dialog look too complex to you?  [reply] Comment 14 Michael Valenta 2007-03-23 09:56:27 EDT That's a good starting point. Here's my comments:  1) I don't think we need the option to skip the dialog. Project Set imports happen infrequently enough that we can justify prompting for the repository information every time.  2) The use of the ... button is not really a standard Platform practice. Also, the location selection dialog is a bit busy. Instead, perhaps we could use a drop down list in the table to allow the user to select an existing repository location. If not matching locations exist, we can prime the field with the location from the project set.  3) To deal with repository location creation, we could add a Create Location button to the dialog that would launch the Create Location wizard. If an entry is selected when we launch the wizard, we could prime the fields with the values from the Project set. When the user has created the location, we could insert it into the location entry of the selected row.  4) Finally, I don't think we need the option to use the location from the project set. I think users only do this now because they have no option. Given the choice, they would rather use a location that has a fixed user name.  How does that sound?  [reply] Comment 15 Tomasz Zarna 2007-04-19 11:22:15 EDT Created attachment 64314 [details] Second (still rough) version of the patch  Instead of making another screen shot I've decided to create this patch. Although it still needs some polishing I belive it can be the answer for your suggestions Michael.  List of things that need to be done: * I would like to have a drop down list for a combo-box made of compatible CVS locations + rest (in that order) * To decide which repository locations are alternative I will take a method used in "Change Sharing..." dialog from a project's properties * As you suggested in comment 12 I will need to use IUserAuthenticator's extension point (instead of creating second one) * I've removed final modifier removed for LoadInfo.repositoryLocation... I was also thinking about creating a new copy of LoadInfo based on an existing one, and then replacing them. I'm not sure which solution is better, less invasive * I would like to add validation of the newly configured, alternative CVS repository (as in NewLocationWizard) * I will need to work on columns width in the table * When a user decide not to overwrite a project from a project set I will need to hide it's repository location from the table (don't need to ask for an alternative repository if we won't import the project)  Michael, if you could tell me if I'm on a good track...  [reply] Comment 16 Tomasz Zarna 2007-04-19 11:22:18 EDT Created attachment 64315 [details] mylar/context/zip  [reply] Comment 17 Michael Valenta 2007-04-19 16:30:48 EDT I think we are going in the right direction but I have a few comments:  1) It appears that only repository locations for which a matching location can be found are shown in the table. It is more likely that there are no repositories defined when the user imports so we need to handle that case. By default, you could file the right column with the location as it would appear if the user didn't change it. As a test for this, create a working set and then start Eclipse on a new workspace and import the working set. When I tried this I got the old prompt. If there are projects from multiple repositories in the project set and I have one of them defined, only the projects for the define repository are imported.  2) Perhaps we should use a TitleAreaDialog and add a description that explains to the user what is going on (i.e. the project set contains partial repository information and we need to get the rest of the information.  3) Canceling the dialog doesn't cancel the operation.  4) The table columns didn't take up all the available space but should.  5) I find the table rows very narrow. Can we add margins to the top and bottom of each row?  6) When creating the location, I had the validate checkbox checked but my location wasn't validated (i.e. I could enter an invalid repository).  [reply] Comment 18 Tomasz Zarna 2007-04-20 11:41:04 EDT Created attachment 64457 [details] Patch v3  Here it is. Michael, the patch is addressing all your last comments and my todos from comment 15.  [reply] Comment 19 Michael Valenta 2007-04-20 15:49:33 EDT Here are some comments:  1) For me, if extssh was in the project set, the New Location Wizard will say pserver. The repository and repository path are there but the connection method isn't.  2) It would be nice if the text on the New Location Wizard said Create instead of Finish.  3) You removed the code that made the repository known. The result of this is that, if the user supplies a password but doesn't save it, they will get prompted later in the operation for the password again.  The good news is that you are most of the way there. The bad news is that I think the change is a bit too big to make at this point. I would like to put it aside for now and we can revisit it at the beginning of 3.4. That will provide plenty of opportunity to get feedback from users.  [reply] Comment 20 Tomasz Zarna 2007-07-09 13:11:24 EDT Created attachment 73350 [details] Patch v4  Michael, if you could take a look at the patch once again. Here are my comments/questions to the fourth version of it:  1) Can team project set file contain any passwords? If yes, should I use them to prime the dialog when creating a new location? 2) In order to change the Finish button label to "Create" I made finishButton field protected (was private). See org.eclipse.jface.wizard.WizardDialog. I'm not sure if it's acceptable. 3) What do you think about the dialog's initial height? Don't you think it's to small? Should I implement storing/loading of the dialog's size? 4) I was also thinking about using ControlDecoration to indicate whether suggested alternative repository is an existing one, needs to be created or it's a perfect match. I've found two bugs related to the topic: bug 162497 and 162770. How to you find the idea? 5) The wizard and the dialog are missing context help.  I will be happy to hear your comments.  [reply] Comment 21 Michael Valenta 2007-07-10 12:45:11 EDT In general, I think the mapping works well but we still need some refinements to the patch.  First, here are my answers to your questions:  1) The project set doesn't contain passwords 2) We can't change API in JFace. I think you can do what you want by overriding the createButton method and looking for the FINISH id. 3) Yes, the dialog is initially too small. We should set the initial size a bit bigger and use the API from  Dialog to remember the users size settings (see Dialog#getDialogBoundsSettings) 4) I'm not sure if this would help. You may try it out if you like but I think it can wait until my points below are addressed. 5) Add the context constants and log a bug to provide the doc (although you can add the TOC entries now if you like)  Here are some comments about the patch:  A) I think the dialog needs to be explained well. It is not obvious from looking at the table what the purpose of the dialog is. I think users will be confused when they are first presented with the dialog. I think we either need to expand the description or add a label that says something like:  The project set only contains partial repository information. Please use the table below to associate each project set repository with a repository location or click OK to use the default locations.  It would also be good if we could convey somehow that, if the user clicks OK, the old behavior still occurs.  B) In keeping with point A, I think we could exclude the connection method from the left column but leave the default in the right column the same (i.e. show the connection method). The column titles could be "Project set repository information" and "Repository Location".  C) In the constructor of AlternativeRepositoryDialog, you make use of an inner class to convert a map to the entries for the table. I think a better approach is this: - make fAlternatives an instance variable of  AlternativeRepositoryTable - create the instance of AlternativeRepositoryTable in the AlternativeRepositoryDialog constructor. The AlternativeRepositoryTable would take a map and translate it to the internal representation. - add a createControl(Composite) to AlternativeRepositoryTable that you call from AlternativeRepositoryDialog#createDialogArea I think this results in better encapsulation.  D) Why does IUserAuthenticator#promptForAlternativeRepository return an Object. It should return a Map. Also, why does it take a Map as a parameter. Shouldn't it just take the list of repositories from the project set?  E) I don't like the use of "Alternative" everywhere. I understand why you used it but I would prefer a different prefix. For instance, in the CVSProjectSetCapability I think that the isAlternativeRepositoryNeeded method could be changed to isAdditionRepositoryInformationRequired and the promptForAlternativeRespository could be changed to promptForAdditionRepositoryInformation.  I think that's it for now.  [reply] Comment 22 Tomasz Zarna 2007-07-13 12:36:29 EDT Created attachment 73754 [details] Patch v5  Here is the fifth version of the patch. I'm pretty sure it's not a final one, but I hope I'm getting closer to a solution which will satisfy both of us :)  Once again, here are my concerns/things to-do: 1) I removed final modifier for CVSProjectSetCapa$LoadInfo.location in order to be able replace it after the Alternative Repo dialog is closed. Is this acceptable? I can create a copy (clone) of project load object before replacing repository location.  2) I subclassed ConfigurationWizardMainPage and change its validation method a little bit. Now, when user tries to create an existing location an error message shows up saying that he/she should close the dialog and select the entry with that location in the combo box. The other solution is to allow create that location, instead of displaying an error (silently handle an error). I could select the existing location after the dialog is closed without creating a new location.  3) Answering to the second part of bullet D - the map is created in isAlternativeRepositoryNeeded. The fact that it's not empty (it contains repository locations from a project set mapped to a list of suggested known locations) is one of the factors which decide to prompt for an additional information (ask user to select an alternative repository from a list). Otherwise (the map is empty) we do not display the Alternative Repository dialog. Do you think I should postpone the creation of the map and check whether the dialog needs to display other way?  4) I will complete and polish my javadocs.  5) I will log a separate bug to extend the doc.  6) I will log a separate bug to provide some tests.  [reply] Comment 23 Michael Valenta 2007-07-16 12:57:22 EDT I think we're getting closer but I'm finding it hard to keep track of what changes from patch to patch. To simplify things, I've released the patch to branch "bug_159258". That way we can incrementally improve things more easily. You should load the branch and provide patches from that. Here are my latest comments  - In regards to the use of a Map, it just seems odd to accept a map as a parameter and return one as well. However, I don;t view this as a big issue so I'll leave it to you to decide what to do. - I don't really like making instance variables directly accessible to subclasses. In the particular case of the NewLocationWizard, you should be able to get around it by creating a protected createMainPage method which you can override in the subclass. You can then call super.addPages() from the subclass add pages to avoid the duplication of the setting of the properties. - I still don't think that "alternative" is the proper term to use everywhere. How about the following renames: AlternativeRepositoryDialog -> ConfigureRepositoryLocationsDialog (or ConfigureProjectSetRepositoriesDialog) AlternativeRepositoryTable -> ConfigureReposiotryLocationsTable  P.S. I didn't include the doc project in the branch but I did include the other 3 plug-ins. summary: [Doc] Pruning always happens when checking out from a branch
description: [Doc] Pruning always happens when checking out from a branch [reply] Description Bruce 2006-10-02 14:09:22 EDT In Eclipse 3.2, empty folders do not appear in the navigator view when a projected is checked out. "Prune empty directories" is turned off.  Team -> Synchronize also fails to bring in the empty directory. This was a problem in Eclipse 3.1. See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=117515  The only way I found to get empty directories from CVS is to check out the project and then use "Replace with latest" from branch.  [reply] Comment 1 Michael Valenta 2006-10-02 14:20:07 EDT In 3.2.1, I performed a checkout with pruning turned off and the empty directories were included. If this doesn't work for you, please provide the exact steps to reproduce (and please use 3.2.1 as it is the latest release).  [reply] Comment 2 Bruce 2006-10-02 15:10:07 EDT This does not work for me using Eclipse 3.2.1.  Start with a project in CVS containing at least one folder that has an empty sub-folder. i.e. myProject/xmlFolder/emptyFolder. The project should not be in your workspace. If it is in your workspace, delete your project and all contents.  Check out the project from CVS. The project exists in your workspace. The subfolders (xmlFolder) exist. But the empty folder (emptyFolder) does not exist.  Right click on the project or parent folder (xmlFolder) and replace the project or parent folder with latest from CVS. The empty folder will appear.  [reply] Comment 3 Michael Valenta 2006-10-02 15:36:51 EDT Here's what I did:  1) Turned off pruning (i.e. unchecked the Prune empty directories preference on the Files and Folders tab of the Team/CVS preference page.  2) Perform an Import and chose Projects from CVS  3) Selected an appropriate repository and project  4) Resulting project in my workspace had empty directories present at both the root and nested within other directories  These steps work for me in both 3.2.1 and 3.3 M2. Are you doing something different?  [reply] Comment 4 Bruce 2006-10-02 17:12:07 EDT Mike,  Thanks for trying to reproduce this.  Step 1 is the same. But I used the CVS perspective to check out the project.  After seeing your response, I tried File -> Import -> CVS -> Projects form CVS as you describe in step 2. I did not get the empty folder.  I wonder if it is a problem with our version of CVS. We are using version 1.11.  Here are the log messages from the CVS console. cvs co -d "XisTestDoc3" -r "i0ptd92" "/iDev/Publications/XmlInformationSystem/XisTestDocProjects/Source/XMLdoc/en/XisTestDoc3" cvs server: Updating XisTestDoc3/xml/TopicCollectionFragment2.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/TopicCollectionFragment3.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/XisTestDoc1.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/XisTestDoc3.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/bookTest1.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/dogTopic4.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/dogTopic77.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/dogTopicCollection.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/dogTopicContent.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/jp_DSFstandaloneBook.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/jp_DSFstandaloneEdoc.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/nestedErrorMessageBlock.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/pl_DSFstandaloneBook.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/pl_DSFstandaloneEdoc.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/refClassCollectionNick1.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/refClassNick1.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/topic4.xml U XisTestDoc3/xml/topic77.xml cvs server: Updating XisTestDoc3/xml/test ok (took 0:01.718) ***  cvs server: Updating xml/test  [reply] Comment 5 Bruce 2006-10-02 17:23:30 EDT cvs -v  Concurrent Versions System (CVS) 1.11.6 (client/server) [SAS Enhanced]  Copyright (c) 1989-2003 Brian Berliner, david d `zoo' zuhn, Jeff Polk, and other authors  CVS may be copied only under the terms of the GNU General Public License, a copy of which can be found with the CVS distribution kit.  [reply] Comment 6 Michael Valenta 2006-10-03 09:20:06 EDT 1.11.6 is a supported version. Can you try the steps at this URL to get a protocol trace?  http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/CVS_FAQ#Is_there_any_equivalent_to_CVS_CLIENT_LOG_is_Eclipse.3F  That may tell us if there is something different happening with your "SAS enhanced" server.  [reply] Comment 7 Bruce 2006-10-03 10:16:38 EDT Created attachment 51336 [details] CVS Trace for checking out an empty directory with CVS 1.11.6  The trace captured the information returned from CVS for the empty directory (XisTestDoc3/xml/test/). Earlier information was not captured. Let me know if you need more information.  [reply] Comment 8 Michael Valenta 2006-10-03 11:44:21 EDT It would appear that there is extra information provided for folders in your customized folders:  Set-sticky XisTestDoc3/xml/ /cvs/cvs_vertical/iDev/Publications/XmlInformationSystem/XisTestDocProjects/Sour ce/XMLdoc/en/XisTestDoc3/xml/ Ti0ptd92  The 3rd line (Ti0ptd92) is not standard CVS. This must be throwing off the empty directory creation. We generally do not support these types of customizations but would be happy to accept a patch that improves the robustness of the parser to properly ignore the extra information.  [reply] Comment 9 Bruce 2006-10-03 17:46:41 EDT Mike,  Are you checking out projects from HEAD or from a branch? I found that checking out a project from HEAD does return empty directories. I am checking out a project from branch i0ptd92. The branch is the information returned in the third line.  I followed up with our CVS support team and reviewed the CVS documentation. I found that prune empty directories is the default when you checkout a project and specify a branch with the -r option. There appears to be no option to turn off pruning. http://ximbiot.com/cvs/wiki/index.php?title=CVS--Concurrent_Versions_System_v1.12.12.1:_Guide_to_CVS_commands#SEC172  Can you confirm that you do not get empty directories when checking out a project from a branch?  This behavior is not documented in the CVS preference documentation for the prune empty directory option. Let me know if you want me to open a defect for the documentation.  [reply] Comment 10 Michael Valenta 2006-10-04 09:42:20 EDT It's all coming back to me now. That is exactly the case. We have code that will always prune if -D or -r is specified. we will update our doc to reflect this. [reply] Comment 13 Michael Valenta 2007-05-25 10:00:02 EDT Verified in I20070525-0010  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: File dirty after saving compare editor
description: File dirty after saving compare editor [reply] Description John Arthorne 2006-10-02 17:01:00 EDT Build id: I20060926-0935  Can't remember if I told you about this...  1) Open some file in a Java editor that is shared with CVS 2) Edit and save the file, but keep the Java editor open 3) Click the file in the sync view to open a compare editor 4) Modify the file in the compare editor.  Now both editors show as dirty (so far so good). 5) Hit Ctrl+S in the compare editor.  The compare editor's dirty flag goes away, but the Java editor still appears dirty. 6) Activate the Java editor.  It says the file has changed externally.  Since they share the same buffer, saving one editor should clear the dirty state of both.  [reply] Comment 1 Michael Valenta 2006-10-03 09:27:43 EDT *** Bug 158798 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***  [reply] Comment 2 Michael Valenta 2006-10-03 12:01:24 EDT These steps don't cause the problem everytime. It appears to be related to the workbench Saveables support. Once that gets involved, a different path through the save logic occurs and we write the file direclty instead of saving through the document provider.  [reply] Comment 3 Michael Valenta 2006-10-03 12:07:30 EDT I also appears that, once a reload is forced in the regular editor, the regular editor and the compare editor end up using different buffers. This means that the compare editor needs to detect external changes and reobtain the buffer when that occurs.  [reply] Comment 4 Michael Valenta 2006-10-10 14:03:55 EDT The problem also occurs when an element in the Structure pane is selected. In this case, the proper document is used but the save state is not synchronized. I should be able to work out a fix for M3 but it will require changes to clients (e.g. Java and PDE).  [reply] Comment 5 Michael Valenta 2006-10-11 13:36:03 EDT I have released the Team changes to HEAD and provded patches to Java and PDE. I will close this once those changes have been released.  [reply] Comment 6 Michael Valenta 2006-10-17 14:36:33 EDT All patches released  [reply] Comment 7 Bogdan Gheorghe 2006-10-31 14:03:53 EST Verified in  I20061031-0656  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [Viewers] getRowPart(Point) behaves differently on Table than on Tree
description: [Viewers] getRowPart(Point) behaves differently on Table than on Tree [reply] Description Thomas Schindl 2006-10-03 10:58:49 EDT getRowPart(Point) is reacting different between on TableViewer and TreeViewer: TableViewer: ------------ protected Item getItem(int x, int y) { return table.getItem(new Point(x, y)); } TreeViewer: ----------- protected Item getItem(int x, int y) { return getTree().getItem(getTree().toControl(new Point(x, y))); } [reply] Comment 1 Thomas Schindl 2006-10-03 11:00:04 EDT Created attachment 51338 [details] patch [reply] Comment 2 Thomas Schindl 2006-10-03 11:28:42 EDT Although this patch syncs the behaviour of getItem(int x, int y) between TableViewer and TreeViewer I'm uncertain that instead of calculating the x/y back and forth like done in #159600 I think we should use add an abstract method which doesn't need us todo that. [reply] Comment 3 Thomas Schindl 2006-10-03 11:31:16 EDT Created attachment 51343 [details] Remove back and forth calculation This makes patch in #159600 obsolete because we don't need to convert relative coordinates to absolute and then back [reply] Comment 4 Thomas Schindl 2006-10-03 11:54:43 EDT Created attachment 51347 [details] Added missing JavaDoc [reply] Comment 5 Tod Creasey 2006-10-03 15:26:40 EDT Do we think adding the extra API for absolute coordinates is neccessary - i.e. will anyone do anything other than the default? I think your first patch is the better solution as it is a more contained fix. [reply] Comment 6 Boris Bokowski 2006-10-03 15:32:51 EDT Less API is a good thing. [reply] Comment 7 Thomas Schindl 2006-10-03 18:26:35 EDT Well on the otherside is it really natural if we have relative coordinates to transform them to absolute ones and afterwards transform them back to relative ones, or did I read the whole thing in the wrong way: 1. TooltipSupport: MouseEvent => coordinates relative to Widget 2. TooltipSupport: Transform them to absolute coordinates on Display 3. TooltipSupport: TreeViewer#getItem(x,y) transform the coordinates back to relative ones. I think the problematic implementation is the one TreeViewer#getItem() which wants to get absolute coordinates (Tod you are contradicting yourself there because at the moment we have an API for absolute coordinates :-). TableViewer#getItem() needs to be fixed to behave like it does in TreeViewer but from my point of view getItem(x,y) implementation is very strange because I'd expect them to work just like Tree#getItem(Point) and Table#getItem(Point). I'd deprecate getItem(x,y) (which might not be possible because it's part of StructuredViewer) and advertise the new API but if we decide against the new API we need to adjust the JavaDoc of ColumnViewer#getRowPart(Point) and we should force people to implement getItem(x,y) by declaring it abstract in ColumnViewer. I'm not happy to add new API functions but the old getItem(int x, int y) doesn't really make sense but it's not really a problem if we/you decide against it. [reply] Comment 8 Boris Bokowski 2006-10-03 21:03:09 EDT TableViewer.getItem(int,int) does not implement the spec in StructuredViewer and needs to be fixed to use display coordinates: StructuredViewer.getItem(int,int) * Returns the item at the given display-relative coordinates, or * null if there is no item at that location. You are correct that StructuredViewer.getItem is inconsistent with Table/Tree.getItem. But after fixing TableViewer.getItem to implement the spec, I don't see the need to add new API, I can live with the redundant coordinate transformations. For ColumnViewer#getRowPart(Point) we need to specify if it takes display coordinates or coordinates relative to the underlying control. [reply] Comment 9 Thomas Schindl 2006-10-04 03:32:15 EDT Created attachment 51395 [details] Patch to fix coordinate inconsitency without bloating the API - Fix TableViewer#getItem() - map absolute coordinates to relative ones - Fix ColumnViewer#getRowPart(Point): - document that coordinates are relative to control - map relative coordinates to absolute ones to use them in getItem() - ColumnViewer#getCell(Point) - document that coordinates are relative to control [reply] Comment 10 Thomas Schindl 2006-10-04 03:35:02 EDT Created attachment 51396 [details] Fix javadoc wording [reply] Comment 11 Tod Creasey 2006-10-04 07:47:56 EDT I think we should be consistent StructuredViewer.getItem(int,int) * Returns the item at the given display-relative coordinates, or * null if there is no item at that location. uses disaply relative so so should getRowPart - having two different co-ordinate systems would be too confusing to developers [reply] Comment 12 Thomas Schindl 2006-10-04 07:59:41 EDT (In reply to comment #11) > I think we should be consistent > > StructuredViewer.getItem(int,int) > * Returns the item at the given display-relative coordinates, or > * null if there is no item at that location. > > uses disaply relative so so should getRowPart - having two different > co-ordinate systems would be too confusing to developers > I tend to agree with you BUT I think most of the developers find the current implementation of getItem()/getRowPart() confusing because the function is normally only called from within the current widget and I as a developer would be confused to calculate my widget relative coordinates to display relatives. As a sidenote the TableViewer#getItem(int,int)-implementation was introduced in 3.3 in 3.2 you'll get null. [reply] Comment 13 Thomas Schindl 2006-10-04 11:30:49 EDT Would it be a acceptable to modify getRowPart(Point point) to getRowPart(Point point, boolean relative2widget)? [reply] Comment 14 Thomas Schindl 2006-10-16 10:55:47 EDT Because we stopped integration widget independency the patch from "2006-10-03 11:00" could be applied to HEAD => afterwards bug #159600 should go in [reply] Comment 15 Boris Bokowski 2006-10-16 12:34:29 EDT First patch released >20061016. [reply] Comment 16 Boris Bokowski 2006-11-01 10:59:45 EST Verified using I20061031-0656. Add Comment Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: bundle org.eclipse.equinox.cm fails to start on OSGi Min/RM
description: bundle org.eclipse.equinox.cm fails to start on OSGi Min/RM [reply] Description Ruibin Zhou 2006-10-04 15:12:27 EDT We had the bundle org.eclipse.equinox.cm_3.2.0.200609272246.jar built from the Eclipse project org.eclipse.equinox.cm, then tried to start it on the stand-alone Equinox 3.2.1 running on J9 (version 2.2) against JCL RM (J9 -jcl:rm), and OSGiMin 11 implementation. The bundle org.eclipse.equinox.cm failed to start with the following exception:  org.osgi.framework.BundleException: Exception in org.eclipse.equinox.cm.internal .Activator.start() of bundle org.eclipse.equinox.cm. at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContextImpl.startActiv ator(BundleContextImpl.java:1010) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContextImpl.start(Bund leContextImpl.java:966) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleHost.startWorker(Bundl eHost.java:317) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.AbstractBundle.start(Abstrac tBundle.java:256) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkCommandProvider._st art(FrameworkCommandProvider.java:239) at java.lang.reflect.AccessibleObject.invokeV(AccessibleObject.java:205)  at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:253) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkCommandInterpreter. execute(FrameworkCommandInterpreter.java:145) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkConsole.docommand(F rameworkConsole.java:293) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkConsole.console(Fra meworkConsole.java:278) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.FrameworkConsole.run(Framewo rkConsole.java:213) at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:719) Nested Exception: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: java.text.DateFormat at org.eclipse.equinox.cm.internal.LogTracker.<init>(LogTracker.java:48)  at org.eclipse.equinox.cm.internal.Activator.start(Activator.java:26) at org.eclipse.osgi.framework.internal.core.BundleContextImpl$2.run(Bund leContextImpl.java:991) ---------  Note that the Equinox 3.2 had the similar problem described in bug 149892 (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=149892), which has been fixed in Equinox 3.2.1.  [reply] Comment 1 Simon Archer 2006-10-04 16:12:01 EDT Looking at the source it seems that org.eclipse.equinox.cm is built against the OSGi Foundation Execution Environment, rather than the OSGi Minimum Execution Environment.  This is truly unfortunate.  I took a quick look and I see the following classes are used, which are not available in the OSGi Minimum Execution Environment:  - DateFormat - HashMap - LinkedList - TreeMap - TreeSet  Also:  - The File method listFiles() is not defined.   In the past I've survived without DateFormat by using Calendar, but of course locale specific formatting is therefore not possible, or at least a lot harder.  This is clearly not a case where date/time formatting justifies using the large Execution Environment.  All uses of HashMap can be replaced with Hashtable.  If you've typed your declarations to the Map interface then this should be an easy fix.  Regarding LinkedList, TreeMap and TreeSet, I would suggest using some Collection available in the Minimum Execution Environment, or else implement your own.  Again, not really something that justifies the larger Execution Environment.  This might not be an exhustive list of issues.  [reply] Comment 2 Simon Archer 2006-10-04 19:07:35 EDT Wow, it seems that the ee.minimum.jar that I have been compiling against was dated 5/26/2005, and seems to be the OSGi Minimum 1.0.  Thanks to John W Ross for pointing out the error of my ways.  So, now that I'm using the ee.minimum.jar for OSGi Minimum 1.1 I can happily report that the only compilation error is due to the use of DateFormat.  As I mentioned before, working around this is possibly using Calendar.  As it turns out, bug 14982 discusses exactly this and Tom attached a patch he created to work around a similar problem:  https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=149892#c10  Thanks, and sorry for the fire drill.  [reply] Comment 3 Simon Archer 2006-10-04 19:22:50 EDT The ee.minimum.jar I was using had been copied from the Equinox project org.eclipse.osgi straight out of CVS, so maybe that one needs to be updated.  Maybe Tom knows.  [reply] Comment 4 Simon Kaegi 2006-10-04 23:48:49 EDT Created attachment 51448 [details] Patch replacing DateFormat  Hi Simon,  I think you're proposing something like this patch. It seems fine and looks harmless as DateFormat is not central to the cm implemtation. Ruibin, does this patch work for you? (the patch sets the Bundle-RequiredExecutionEnvironment, however I did not get a chance to try this in min 1.1 environment)  -- As an aside... One thing I'm less comfortable with is that this code will likely need to be repeated elsewhere. (see bug 142138) We can certainly commit a polished version of this patch, but I'd like to avoid creating future inconsistency if possible.  [reply] Comment 5 Simon Kaegi 2006-10-04 23:52:59 EDT Created attachment 51450 [details] Patch replacing DateFormat  (missed the import in the last patch)  [reply] Comment 6 Simon Archer 2006-10-05 09:41:52 EDT Yes, I tried the patch and it looks good.  Sadly it is tricky to know where code such as this could reside such that others could use it.  Maybe Tom can suggest somewhere.  The .classpath still needs to be updated since it refers to "CDC-1.0%Foundation-1.0".  Thanks  [reply] Comment 7 Ruibin Zhou 2006-10-05 10:49:07 EDT I also tried the patch, now it works fine on J9 with -JCL:RM.  [reply] Comment 8 Thomas Watson 2006-10-06 09:42:56 EDT (In reply to comment #3) > The ee.minimum.jar I was using had been copied from the Equinox project > org.eclipse.osgi straight out of CVS, so maybe that one needs to be updated. > Maybe Tom knows.  I have been reluctant to move the core Equinox framework off of ee min 1.0.  This will temp us to start checking in code that will not run on older VMs.  At some point this will become less important when the VMs that support ee min 1.1 have been released for a while.  [reply] Comment 9 Thomas Watson 2006-10-06 09:48:03 EDT (In reply to comment #6) > Yes, I tried the patch and it looks good.  Sadly it is tricky to know where > code such as this could reside such that others could use it.  Maybe Tom can > suggest somewhere.  It is difficult to pick such a place.  I don't want to start adding more API to the Equinox framework for this.     [reply] Comment 10 Simon Kaegi 2006-10-17 00:00:29 EDT [Patch submitted to HEAD] I've also updated and tested with an ee min 1.1 classpath as per Simon's suggestion. (I'll track the LogTracker differences in bug 142138)  [reply] Comment 11 McQ Wilson 2007-01-15 13:43:48 EST Is this something that we could fix for R3.2.2?  [reply] Comment 12 Thomas Watson 2007-01-15 13:50:29 EST No, org.eclipse.equinox.cm has not graduated from the incubator and does not exist in 3.2.2.  We are looking to graduate it in 3.3. summary: get adviceDidNotMatch warning as well as "advises" for piece of advice in project on aspectpath
description: get adviceDidNotMatch warning as well as "advises" for piece of advice in project on aspectpath [reply] Description Helen Beeken 2006-10-05 09:42:26 EDT An "adviceDidNotMatch" warning is reported against a piece of advice that matches somewhere in a project whose aspectpath it is on. The result is that you get both an "adviceDidNotMatch" warning as well as the "advises" marker.  I'm in two minds whether this is an aspectj or ajdt bug. As yet I have not been able to write an AJ testcase which demonstrates the problem. I'm leaning towards it being an AJDT bug because it's ajdt which places the "advises" marker against the advice in the project which is on the aspectpath.  [reply] Comment 1 Helen Beeken 2006-10-05 09:47:35 EDT Created attachment 51471 [details] testcase  To recreate this bug:  1. unzip the attachment into your workspace 2. build aj1 3. open aj1\pkg\A.aj - you should see an "adviceDidNotMatch" warning (which is correct since this project only knows about itself so thinks the advice doesn't match anywhere) 4. build aj2 5. aj1\pkg\A.aj now shows that it both advises the method call and that the advice did not apply.  [reply] Comment 2 Helen Beeken 2006-10-05 09:48:41 EDT Note that the only dependency between the two projects is that one is on the aspect path of the other.  [reply] Comment 3 Matt Chapman 2006-10-09 16:36:06 EDT Fixed in:  1.4.1.200610091249 for Eclipse 3.2 (build.214) 1.5.0.200610091244 for Eclipse 3.3M2 (build.51)  Now when you build aj1 you get the "adviceDidNotMatch" warning, as expected. Then when aj2 is built, it adds the advises relationship and removes the warning from aj1. If aj1 is rebuilt, the added relationship is removed, and the warning returns. I think this is the most appropriate behaviour, so that stale relationships are not left behind. In a setup like this I think it's more useful for aj2 to depend on aj1, so that if aj1 is rebuilt, then aj2 will be also.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: Team - Create Patch does not respect file line endings
description:
Team - Create Patch does not respect file line endings [reply] Description Rob 2006-10-05 11:41:57 EDT When I create a patch, the line endings are ALWAYS Windows (I'm on XP, Eclipse 3.2). How can I easily create CVS patches with Unix line endings without opening and manually converting each patch file in Eclipse or Notepad++?  I have Project line endings set to Unix in my Workspace -> New text file line delim prefs and even have tried unchecking Team > CVS > Files and folders > Convert text files to use platform line ending. I'm thinking the patch should just check whatever the Workspace prefs line endings are and use those.  [reply] Comment 1 Bogdan Gheorghe 2006-10-10 17:36:34 EDT We would be happy to accept a patch for this. The DiffOperation class is responsible for writing out the patch and it currently uses stream.println. This would need to be changed to take into account the current workspace line ending setting.  [reply] Comment 2 Krzysztof Daniel 2007-02-12 09:15:07 EST In the DiffOperation the stream is initialized by _abstract_ method openStream, so any changes will affect all subclasses of DiffOperation.  I would like to avoid subclassing PrintStream and changing its behavior, although it seems to be the fastest way, and I would like to avoid major changes in those classes, too.  So, maybe it is good idea to request changes from Sun (customizable line endings)?  [reply] Comment 3 Michael Valenta 2007-02-13 09:15:28 EST I guess you could ask them but that is not really a solution to the problem. It wouldn't be difficult to write the bytes directly to an OutputStream using the same line endings from the original file in the patch.  [reply] Comment 4 Krzysztof Daniel 2007-02-14 04:33:16 EST Migrating to OutputStream will not be difficult, however it may slightly change current API.  But from where line ending style should be retrieved? Workspace? Project?  Maybe it is good to add new section on advanced tab of create patch wizard, which should have 3 radios: 1. win 2. *nix 3. macos  The section should be active only if patch will be created to file, and initial selection would be:  patch into filesystem: system line ending patch into workspace: workspace/project line ending.  I do not see any reason to take care about clipboard line ending.  While approaching the problem this way we can avoid any manipulation of API, just in a method org.eclipse.team.internal.ccvs.ui.operations.FileDiffOperation.copyFile() invoke file ending conversion.  On the sun pages there was similar request, however all are 'WONTFIX'.  [reply] Comment 5 Michael Valenta 2007-02-14 08:21:04 EST I think it would be easiest if the line endings in the patch matched the line endings in the file from which the patch was generated.  [reply] Comment 6 Krzysztof Daniel 2007-02-14 08:27:51 EST but please imagine many projects in the workspace with different encodings. Created patch is one, what implicates either some kind of brute conversion or different line endings in one file (which seems to be weird, however should work nice).  [reply] Comment 7 Krzysztof Daniel 2007-02-16 08:40:09 EST Created attachment 59133 [details] A draft of solution preserving line endings (NOT A PATCH)  This is quick fix for this bug if the function IResource#getLineDelimiter() were available. This function exists: org.eclipse.core.internal.filebuffers.TextFileBufferManager.getLineDelimiterPreference(IPath), but is not visible. Feature 174429 has been requested.  This fix will preserve line endings but does nothing to headers like ### Eclipse Workspace Patch 1.0 #P org.eclipse.team.cvs.ui Index: src/org/eclipse/team/internal/ccvs/ui/operations/DiffOperation.java  Those line endings should be investigated further.  [reply] Comment 8 Krzysztof Daniel 2007-02-19 09:08:50 EST Created attachment 59257 [details] Fix preserving line endings  System defaults are ignored. Preferences are ignored. Line endings are preserved from processed file. Wrapper to BufferedReader has been added as internal class.  [reply] Comment 9 Krzysztof Daniel 2007-02-19 09:10:42 EST Created attachment 59258 [details] Test cases for proposed patch  [reply] Comment 10 Michael Valenta 2007-02-19 16:10:34 EST I've had a look at the patch and the general idea looks correct. However, I think you should not be testing for "ready" before returning the value. What ready says is that there are buffered contents available in the underlying reader so the read will not block. However, it doesn't say that there aren't more characters coming. Under certain circumstances, I believe the code in the patch could return a single line as two separate lines. I think the text you are looking for is something like this:  int c = br.read(); if (c == -1) // there is no more to read  [reply] Comment 11 Krzysztof Daniel 2007-02-20 03:36:03 EST Created attachment 59351 [details] Fix, suggestion applied  [reply] Comment 12 Krzysztof Daniel 2007-02-20 03:37:52 EST Created attachment 59352 [details] Unit tests  [reply] Comment 13 Michael Valenta 2007-02-20 09:59:05 EST Sorry but I just realized that the patch you have provided only provides the line endings for new files. The problem is that there may be patches for several files in the patch. I think that the patch file should have a single line ending for the whole file and not a different one for each file (which your patch could end up with). I wasn't considering the whole problem in comment 5 and I apologize for that. I think it would be reasonable to consult the CVSProviderPlugin.getPlugin().isUsePlatformLineend() to determine if the platform line ending should be used or if just '
' should be used. This line ending would need to be used for both new files and existing files. The best approach would be to change the stream that is returned from DiffOperation#getOutputStream so that it used the proper line ending.  Again, I apologize for leading you in the wrong direction.  [reply] Comment 14 Krzysztof Daniel 2007-02-21 04:27:10 EST Created attachment 59457 [details] Patches with '
' or default platform line ending  Newly created patches will have default line ending '
' or platform line ending.  I believe this is not complex solution, because I cannot generate windows patch on *nix machine. Michael, I appreciate  your comment on this.  [reply] Comment 15 Michael Valenta 2007-02-21 10:23:27 EST The latest patch is looking better. I do have a couple of questions though:  1) Is there a reason you overrode the print() methods? I would have though that overriding the println methods would be enough.  2) Do we need the platformSettings instance variable. It only appears to be used in the constructor?  [reply] Comment 16 Krzysztof Daniel 2007-02-21 10:40:51 EST 2. You are right, we do not need it.  1. Methods print should be overridden, but I think not all. Calling print('
') causes the new line character being converted to platform new line (PrintStream specification). You can assume, that overriding only the println should be enough (logic suggests, that it should be used internally by PrintStream), however I would not rely on that. Anyway, there is a couple of methods I can remove (almost all with primitives attributes).  [reply] Comment 17 Michael Valenta 2007-02-21 10:54:48 EST Since we are the client, I think it is safe to assume that print is never called with a string that contains a new line character. Also, you are correct in that we cannot assume that the println(arg) methods call the println method. Hence, we should only need to override all the println methods. However, we could override the println methods to call print(arg) and then println() and println() could use print(lineDelimeter) to print the line ending. This way, we wouldn't need to implement the error handling (although it is not a big deal to do so).  [reply] Comment 18 Krzysztof Daniel 2007-02-21 11:17:18 EST Created attachment 59485 [details] Only println methods modified  I cannot use print(newLineCharacter), because the character will be translated according to platform. I have to use primitive write(), but it throws Exception, so I have to handle errors. No other way.  Previous patch (id=59547) seemed to be more reliable (any subclassing of DiffOperation or modifications should not break its functionality).  [reply] Comment 19 Michael Valenta 2007-02-22 12:15:08 EST Patch released to HEAD. Thanks...  [reply] Comment 20 Michael Valenta 2007-03-20 13:43:07 EDT verified  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments
