[reply] Comment 45 Ed Merks 2008-06-05 07:35:48 EDT We actually had alternative ways to avoid modifying generated code before we came up with the JMerge approach.  That approach involved a pair of interfaces, generated and user modifiable, and a pair of classes, again, generated and user modifiable.  The approach was bloated, both in terms of files and in terms of extra byte code; even an empty class or interface leads to very significant overhead. It was also conceptually more complex and was a highly artificial pattern, i.e., not anything like how you'd design it by hand.  Ultimately the approach was abandoned for all these reasons, and a few die hard purists who believe generated code should not be touched weren't so happy about that.  Of course some people will always feel that generated code shouldn't be touched and perhaps not even committed to their repository.  They're entitled to their opinion, but generally change their opinion over time since most tools can't produce 100% satisfactory results.  Given I've been working this way for the last seven years and have never had a bad experience, I'd be curious about the nature of the bad experiences.  Eclipse keeps a history so even overwriting your changes, should you forget to remove @generated from a changed method is easily recoverable.  That's even more the case when you keep your code in a repository. Using the approach of renaming the generated method to *Gen and calling it, you can even ensure the future regenerated changes are picked up.  Of course I can see that actually changing the body of a method and removing @generated means you'll not pick of enhancements in the future, so definitely there are some disadvantages, although if the changes are merely to implement an EOperation in Java, there's not going to be changes in the future.  Of course it's possible to write an operation as an annotation on the operation as well; it's good to keep the purists happy too. :-P  In any case, everyone is definitely entitled to their opinion though I will always argue strongly with anyone who says modifying generated code is just generally a bad practice.  It's one of the pillars that has made EMF successful so if it's bad practice, it's one that has proven highly valuable and broadly appealing.  Touche on the "I-pattern" jibe. :-P Hehehe.  I do think it's an extremely unfortunate choice and I noticed that SWT didn't choose it either...  So sorry for the harsh criticism. I like to see the community function well where everyone's opinions are respected and where folks consider carefully what it's like to be at the receiving end of their commentary.  It's very hard to foster a climate of collaboration since people can and will have many legitimate differences of opinion.  In the ideal world, those differences lead to a diverse community that supports the diverse usage patterns of the users.  It's definitely very constructive to find out what Byran's design philosophy is and compare that to what's driven the project so far.  Do you guys imagine it might be possible to design a syntax other than XML for a workflow?  I guess it needs to be extensible although I could imagine supporting some type of generalized name/property syntax in the base grammar.  I'm a bit sick of XML pretending to be a human-readable syntax and I know you folks are doing some very cool things in that domain.  A workflow language with a nice human readable syntax, a high end editor, perhaps including graphical views of the flows would be pretty cool in the long term.  Did you guys ever write an XML Schema for the XML syntax?  That would certainly help make it clear the intended model of the syntax and what needs to be parsed and printed...  [reply] Comment 46 Sven Efftinge 2008-06-05 08:56:24 EDT  > well; it's good to keep the purists happy too. :-P  Yes, and I'm a happy purist, because I could solve the problem thanks to the mentioned EAnnotation.  > > In any case, everyone is definitely entitled to their opinion though I will > always argue strongly with anyone who says modifying generated code is just > generally a bad practice. We've been thinking about form based, graphical and alternative textual syntaxes (see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=218806). I think the goal is to make it easy to combine different syntaxes for EMF based languages in general by combining GMF, TMF and other technologies. As you know we're currently working on the TMF part. MWE will be one of our first applications for it. Still we need to support the current user base, but that shouldn't be much of a problem in this case.   > > Did you guys ever write an XML Schema for the XML syntax? Instead of writing: ... <parameter name="foo"> <bean class="foo.Bar"> <parameter name="foo" value="bar"/> <parameter name="nested"> <bean class="foo.Bar2"> <parameter name="stuff" value="apa"/> </bean> </parameter> </bean> </parameter> ...  where you could of course come up with a schema declaring 'parameter' and 'bean' we write ... <foo class="foo.Bar" foo="bar"> <nested class="foo.Bar2" stuff="apa"/> </foo> ...  As you see, we use just the syntax of XML (the decision was made in order to not scare users with yet another syntax). We tried hard to make it as non-verbose and readable as possible. Yes, in my use-case, I intend to extend WorkflowUnitOfWork to perform an interesting task (call it ExtendedUnitOfWork).  We will then directly create an instance of the workflow model using instances of WorkflowCompositeComponent and ExtendedUnitOfWork.  There may be cases when an ExtendedUnitOfWork will set the value of a WorkflowParameter that is needed by a subsequent ExtendedUnitOfWork as an input.  The connection of the output parameter to the input parameter will be explicitly modeled.  Using the name of the parameter as a key may not work as they are not guaranteed to be unique, and one ExtenedUnitOfWork is independent of the other meaning it does not care who produced the parameter value as long as it is set before execution.  It may be the case that an admin will assemble a composite from a set of existing components, and stitch the inputs and outputs using WorkflowParameterConnection.  We are also going to extend WorkflowParameter such that the value returned from the parameter is derived from the value in the WorkflowContext instead of the actual value in the WorkflowContext.  Some values in the WorkflowContext will be set by a user using a custom editor and persisted for later use with a workflow model.  Bryan  [reply] Comment 59 Marc Dutoo 2008-07-09 11:37:43 EDT Hi Bryan  Just wanted to say I've included your "custom Action" use case as a requirement for JWT metamodel extension mechanism at http://wiki.eclipse.org/JWT_Metamodel . [reply] Comment 68 Hallvard Traetteberg 2008-09-01 07:07:59 EDT (In reply to comment #66) > I've run across an interesting design issue  If I've understood you correctly, it's similar to a problem I have. In fact, my model in many respects is a process model, although the domain is user interface domain dialog.  In this domain, the data type of a value is often tied to the type of another value, e.g. a list shows data of type T* (or whatever indicates multiple values), while the selection is of type T. It's not only value types that are related, but also return and parameter values of functions.  Initially, my solution was to add parameters to my process-like dialog element class, as key/value pairs, and a special parameter-reference EClass, that may be used as the value of EReferences representing types. I was uncomfortable with this design, for several reasons: - For the modeller, the option of inserting a type parameter was the non-typical case, and it resulted in a confusing user interface. - When parameterizing the a model fragment, it was more natural to say that this part here actually is the same as this other part, instead of introducing a parameter and saying that both these are actually this parameter. - I wanted dialogs to always be complete, and hence wanted to force the modeller to always fill in all parameters. In some sense, filling in a parameter is something that is done afterwards if the default doesn't suit you, and shouldn't be forced upon the user. - Resolving the parameter-reference increased the complexity.  The solution I'm now considering is as follows: - Instead of pointing from the point of usage (ParameterReference) to the defintion (Parameter) I only point from the definition to the point of usage (list of ParameterUsage objects, with a "path" from the container to the point of usage). - Instantiating a parameter involves pointing the definition to the (new) value and patching the point of usage to refer to this new value. In case of containment, the latter my involve copying structure.  This scheme is simpler because it does not require modifications to the model where the parameter is used. It is more generic since it essentially describes how structures are shared, without being tied to a particular meta-model. However, it is more complex for the person defining a parameter, since she must have a better understanding of the meta-model. However, it should be possible to semi-automatically create the ParameterUsage objects, based on searches in the containment tree.  [reply] Comment 69 Bryan Hunt 2008-09-01 09:26:55 EDT (In reply to comment #67) > Configuring a workflow component with a *typed* complex value (instead of just > passing in simple strings, objects etc.) is what I mean when I was talking of > depenency injection. > > IMHO such a feature is vital.  I agree, and this is what I was attempting to do by using SimpleAnyType not realizing that it seems to limit you to an EDataType which rules out complex types.  Although SimpleAnyType extends AnyType which should allow complex types, but I didn't understand AnyType when I looked at it.  If anyone has a pointer to an example of using AnyType, that would be appreciated.  > > Isn't the context about passing dynamic state from component to component where > the configuration of components is a static thing? > I think we need both. >  The context is for passing dynamic state from component to component, and for dynamically configuring components at runtime.  The idea is that a user selects / edits a context that supplies all of the necessary parameter values to the components of a previously modeled workflow.  The current design of the WorkflowContext only allows for mapping parameters to EDataType values - meaning simple types.  I think we both agree that parameter values should be allowed to be typed complex values (EObject).  So it seems that parameters should be typed on EClassifier.  Example:  public class WorkflowParameter { private EClassifier type; private String name; private String description;  public void setType(EClassifier type)  public Object getValue(WorkflowContext context) }  My comment #66 takes this idea a step further.  What if the user's data was an instance of an EMF model, and the parameters mapped to an EStructuralFeature of that model.  I was thinking this would be a better way to model the parameters, but it seems there are problems with this design as well.  Using EStructuralFeature, you still need to map the instance of the object to the parameter so that it knows which object to get the value from using eGet().  So, right now, I don't see the advantage of this design over the current design assuming I can figure out how to use AnyType.  [reply] Comment 70 Bryan Hunt 2008-09-01 09:29:49 EDT (In reply to comment #68) Hallvard, thanks for the comments.  I must admit that I didn't fully understand your description of your solution.  I'm probably not understanding your terminology which can be a very subtle thing that is easily misinterpreted.  If you have time, please take a look at comment #69.  [reply] Comment 71 Ed Merks 2008-09-01 09:40:20 EDT Bryan,  This article shows how to use AnyType.  http://www.theserverside.com/tt/articles/article.tss?l=BindingXMLJava  You might want simply require it to be EObject, which allows AnyType or anything else, and can also use SimpleAnyType to wrap instances of EDataTypes so that they too are EObjects...  [reply] Comment 72 Bryan Hunt 2008-09-01 09:50:15 EDT (In reply to comment #71) > You might want simply require it to be EObject, which allows AnyType or > anything else, and can also use SimpleAnyType to wrap instances of EDataTypes > so that they too are EObjects... >  Ah, I think you have triggered the right brain cells.  If the WorkflowContext maps parameters to EObject, then as you indicate, SimpleAnyType can be used to wrap simple types for storage in the map.  I think this also solves the other problems as well.  I think it's a simple matter of extending WorkflowParameter to know if it's pointing to a SimpleAnyType, complex EObject, or or an EClassifier of an EObject.  It's simple, elegant, and I like it.  Thank you Ed!  [reply] Comment 73 Bryan Hunt 2008-09-01 09:54:39 EDT (In reply to comment #72) > problems as well.  I think it's a simple matter of extending WorkflowParameter > to know if it's pointing to a SimpleAnyType, complex EObject, or or an > EClassifier of an EObject.  Oops, I think I meant EStructuralFeature of an EObject and not EClassifier.  [reply] Comment 74 Bryan Hunt 2008-09-01 10:26:32 EDT Rather than extend WorkflowParameter, I think a value strategy pattern would be better.  [reply] Comment 75 Bryan Hunt 2008-09-01 13:56:49 EDT Created attachment 111429 [details] EMF workflow model  WorkflowContext now maps WorkflowParameter to EObject.  Added WorkflowParameterValueStrategy which simply returns the EObject from the context map and WorkflowParameterSimpleValueStrategy which wraps the parameter value inside a SimpleAnyType.  Instances of WorkflowParameter must have a value strategy.  [reply] Comment 76 Bryan Hunt 2008-09-01 13:57:39 EDT Created attachment 111430 [details] Sample workflows  Updates corresponding to the new workflow model  [reply] Comment 77 Hallvard Traetteberg 2008-09-01 15:50:42 EDT (In reply to comment #70) > Hallvard, thanks for the comments.  I must admit that I didn't fully understand > your description of your solution.  I'll try again. In my previous model, I had a Type interface and specific Type implementations, e.g. ClassType, ListType, including a TypeParameterReference class. The latter could be used to refer by name to a TypeParameter (and its value) of a containing EObject. Code that traversed structures containing the Type objects would need to detect TypeParameterReference and lookup the real TypeParameter value.  The advantage of such parameters in general, is that there is a single place (the TypeParameter's value) to change the value of several references (the value denoted by the TypeParameterReference). In my case, the abstract description of a listbox would contain a TypeParameter T and two references List<T> and T, for the output and input types of the listbox. By setting T to a specific value, like String, you would get a listbox specific for Strings.  There are several disadvantages to this approach, in particular that code everywhere needed to be aware of the mechanism and that it was cumbersome to extend it to other type than Type.  The alternative approach (which I tried to explain) is to discard the TypeReference class, and instead extend the TypeParameter objects to include a list of "paths" to every place where there used be a TypeReference. So, when the TypeParameter's value is changed, it may patch the contained structure to refer directly to the new value. In the example, the listbox would be modeled by List<Object> and Object, for output and input, respectively, with no reference to the TypeParameter. The TypeParameter object would include enough information to locate the references to Object inside the structure and when the TypeParameter's value is set to String, it would replace Object with String.  In general, the TypeParameter needs to be able to navigate to all the relevant contained EObjects and the EStructuralFeature that needs to be set (a bit similar to how an EMF XMI resource uses id fragments, by the way). It shouldn't be too difficult to make TypeParameter lookup its value in other structures and react to changes at this other location.  Hallvard  [reply] Comment 78 Bryan Hunt 2008-09-28 10:39:06 EDT Created attachment 113684 [details] EMF workflow model  Code cleanup  [reply] Comment 79 Bryan Hunt 2008-09-28 10:40:11 EDT Created attachment 113685 [details] Sample workflows  Updates for corresponding changes to the workflow model  [reply] Comment 80 Bryan Hunt 2008-11-30 21:13:09 EST Created attachment 119107 [details] EMF workflow model  Customized the generated editor to allow for the creation of SimpleAnyType as values for parameters.  [reply] Comment 81 Bryan Hunt 2008-12-03 20:38:40 EST Created attachment 119452 [details] EMF workflow model  Fixed problem with SimpleAnyType serialization  [reply] Comment 82 Bryan Hunt 2008-12-04 09:47:38 EST I've put together two screencasts on the workflow model.  The first is a presentation that explains the model, and the second is a step by step tutorial on extending and running the model.  Presentation (1024 x 768, 728 MB): http://idisk.mac.com/bhunt-Public/Workflow.mov Tutorial (1900 x 1200, 1.17 GB): http://idisk.mac.com/bhunt-Public/WorkflowTutorial.mov   [reply] Comment 83 Bryan Hunt 2008-12-11 18:48:41 EST I've committed the core model and unit tests to CVS.  /cvsroot/modeling/org.eclipse.emf/org.eclipse.emf.mwe/plugins/org.eclipse.emf.mwe.ewm.core /cvsroot/modeling/org.eclipse.emf/org.eclipse.emf.mwe/tests/org.eclipse.emf.mwe.ewm.core.tests  [reply] Comment 84 Bryan Hunt 2008-12-13 14:18:51 EST I've committed the workflow launcher with tests to CVS  [reply] Comment 85 Bryan Hunt 2009-02-17 23:16:18 EST I've committed the sample editor with some minor customizations for dealing with SimpleAnyType and the example code I'll be discussing at EclipseCon. summary: AccProbe: display HRESULTs != S_OK
description: AccProbe: display HRESULTs != S_OK Description Mike 2008-04-08 15:03:06 EDT The Accesssibility Properties View currently displays values of properties regardless of the value of the HRESULT value that is returned by the underlying method call.  This is misleading since property values may be seen as empty strings or as null values when, in fact, theHRESULT was S_FALSE, E_NOIMPL, or some other code that indicates that the method that accesses the property is not implemented or that the value is invalid.  These sorts of values sould be displayed in the properties view.  Our strategy for dealing with HRESULT values!= S_OK will be as follows: 1. Define a new protected field, Map errorCodeReturnMap =- new HashMap() in org.eclipse.actf.accservice.win32.msaa.MsaaAccessible and a public method for retreaving it, errorCodeMap(). (Don't make it a getter else PropertyUtils.describe will include it.) 2. You'll populate this map from the native code. Each time you get a value != S_OK, retreave the map with the public method and the handle you get to the accessible object of which it is a member and place the property name (i.e. method name without 'get' and with first char to lower case) or the method name (if it's not a getter) in the map as the key and the error as the value for that key. The error should be a string, which will make (3) easier. Obviously, the retreval of a map for a given accessible object and the put to that map can be static.  I recommend something like:  void putErrorCode(jobject acc, string key, HRESULT errorCode)  I also recommend a public constant like '*** ERROR ***' to indicate that the value that does appear in the properties view is not a legitimate value of a property.  Thus, you might see something like:  accessibleDescription | *** ERROR *** S_FALSE  3. In AccProbe's Properties View, you can simply "dump" the error code map into the map you create for actual return values. For keys that exist in the errorCodeReturnMap, those keys will overwrite keys and values in the actual return value map returned by describe and the other techniques employed to populate the view that you are working on.  Comment 1 Kavitha Teegala 2008-04-23 09:44:33 EDT Fixed.  Comment 2 Mike 2008-04-23 09:46:54 EDT Ted mustverify  Comment 3 Ann Ford 2008-04-23 13:22:55 EDT Ted has verified that this is fixed.  Comment 4 Mike 2008-06-05 13:51:55 EDT none

summary: AccProbe: enhance usability of method invocation
description: AccProbe: enhance usability of method invocation Description Mike 2008-04-08 15:24:50 EDT Currently, any value that is not obtained via a simple accessor in the Accessibility Properties View can be obtained by selecting the desired property (or nested property) and using the Invoke Method.. context menu item.  The problem is that there are too many methods for some classes and interfaces when both the declared methods of the class or interface and all of the methods of the super-classes or super-interfaces of that class are listed.  The current functionality also requires the user to continually input the method parameters even if those parameters do not change.  We'll do the following to enhance functionality: 1. for the value types that are not primitives or strings, display the declared  methods of that value type as subnodes of the property. Display the non-declared methods of that value type in the dialog. 2. Since the non-getter methods will require parameters, all non-accessor methods will have their name displayed as the property and a dummy string such as '<Click to enter parameters>' as their value.  When double-clicked, a dialog for entering the appropriate number of parameters will be displayed and the entered parameters will be cached for future instances of this method invocation. The parameters will be cached so long as the accessible object from which the properties in the properties view are derived is not changed and so long as the user does not double-click the property/method name again to enter new values.  Comment 1 Kavitha Teegala 2008-04-28 18:04:09 EDT 1) Added selection Listener to prorpeties view to bring up methodInvocation Dialog when the treeItem contains the value '<Click to enter parameters>'. Will pass in the method name to be invoked 2)Modified methodInvocationDialog constructor to take in an additional method field. The method comboBox will only contain one method, the one passed in from preoprties view. Simplified the method names to be short. 3)Added to list the type of parameters besides the parameters fields.(such as int)  The rest of the functionality is similar to 'Invoke method'.  One issue I'm seeing is that when I click on one of these propeties (which take parameters) for the first time, I'm seeing two dialog boxes to popup as two selection events are being fired.  Comment 2 Kavitha Teegala 2008-06-27 10:55:39 EDT User will now be able to invoke all public declared methods by double clicking on the property. Ted, please verify.  Comment 3 Kavitha Teegala 2009-03-06 09:45:16 EST Fixed

summary: Right click popup menu inside Local Shell view has two copy entries
description: Right click popup menu inside Local Shell view has two copy entries [reply] Description Dmitry Baev 2008-04-30 17:13:02 EDT Created attachment 98270 [details] multiple copy entries in the menu  Right click popup menu inside Local Shell view has two copy entries  To reproduce the problem:  Launch a new local shell type cd in the command prompt, hit enter type ls in the command prompt, hit enter hit ctrl+a to select all output text mouse right-click to bring up the menu  see screen shot attached.  [reply] Comment 1 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-03 03:38:56 EDT I will take a look at this one.  [reply] Comment 2 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-05 11:09:21 EDT Created attachment 98643 [details] Patch for this bug  After executing the commands there are both IRemoteOutput and IRemoteError (from the "ls" command) objects in the selection. The context menu is built by calling each adapter (SystemViewRemoteOutputAdapter, SystemViewRemoteErrorAdapter) to add actions in the menu. SystemViewRemoteErrorAdapter#addActions is implemented to always call its super which is wrong in the case when we have both RemoteOutput and RemoteError objects and leads to adding the Copy twice. In the proposed patch the selection is checked if it contains only RemoteError objects and only then it adds the content menu actions.  [reply] Comment 3 Martin Oberhuber 2008-05-05 20:05:21 EDT Ok, I see -- in case there is a multi-select which contains only RemoteError objects, the RemoteError action(s) will be added. The RemoteOutput adapter will not be asked in this case.  When the multi-select contains any one element that is not a RemoteError, the RemoteError action(s) will not be added.  This sounds fair enough for me, since in many cases a non-homogeneous multiselect will limit the list of available actions, Project Explorer also does it that way.  Please apply the patch, DaveM please review after the fact if you find any issue with it. When verifying the fix, we should make sure that in case of running a compile command like gcc foo.c on the remote, we can still jump to the location of a compile error properly.  I find the issue itself trivial, since it is only exposed in case of multiselect, and it is harmless.  [reply] Comment 4 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-06 05:43:32 EDT Patch committed.  [reply] Comment 5 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-06 05:44:27 EDT Marking as FIXED  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

Source) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Main.java:549) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:504) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:1236) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:1212)  [reply] Comment 1 Martin Oberhuber 2008-05-02 10:27:37 EDT This is most likely an adapter loading issue due to bug 218304. Thanks for reporting this!  This can only happen when rse.shells.ui (or rse.files.ui) is not yet loaded when you perform the content assist. That is, it must happen very soon after Eclipse startup.  Can you please give exact steps you take for connecting your subsystem (I assume you use "Launch Shell"). We will need to place a  Platform.getAdapterManager().loadAdapter()  call in the proper place of RemoteShellSubsystem.initializeSubSystem() or similar, to force the adapter loading at the right time. Similar to RemoteFileSubSystem.initializeSubSystem().  Could you try to fix it yourself? - I can help out if you think you can't handle it.  [reply] Comment 2 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-02 10:58:44 EDT Martin, you are correct, this happens only if org.eclipse.rse.files.ui is not activated. If I explicitly start this plug-in from the Plug-In Registry view or expand Local Files, the content assist is working fine.  So, the problem is reproduced with Local Shells every time when Local Files is not expanded (org.eclipse.rse.files.ui is not activated).  There is a call to loadAdapter in RemoteCmdSubSystem#initializeSubSystem(): // load UI plugin for adapters right after successful connect Platform.getAdapterManager().loadAdapter(new RemoteOutput(null, ""), "org.eclipse.rse.ui.view.ISystemViewElementAdapter");  It seems that we need also to bring up something else.  [reply] Comment 3 Martin Oberhuber 2008-05-02 11:22:14 EDT Ah, ok. I'm pretty sure that this happens on "local" only and not on ssh or dstore -- because local is special, it is "always connected".  Because it is always connected, the connect() calls are never activated and therefore the file adapters are only loaded when expanding the RSE tree. This is apparently not sufficient for the collaboration between shells and files.  This is a little bit tricky to solve, because we do not want to create unwanted dependencies shells->files or files->shells.  I think the right algorithm is probably this: In the SubSystem#resolveFilterString() methods [3 occurrences] change this code:  if (!supportsConnecting && !_isInitialized) { // Lazy Loading: Load adapters (e.g. Local Subsystem) initializeSubSystem(monitor); }  into initializing all subsystems that share the same connector service:  // Lazy Loading: Load adapters (e.g. Local Subsystem) if (!_isInitialized) { ISubSystem[] ss = getHost().getSubSystems(); for (int i=0; i<ss.length; i++) { if (!ss[i].getSubSystemConfiguration().supportsSubSystemConnect()) { ss[i].initializeSubSystem(new NullProgressMonitor()); } } }  The code needs to be more polished, e.g. put into a separate private method to re-use, and use the _isInitialized variable in order to avoid doing the initialization multiple times. But with this basic idea, in case a subsystem does not support the connect, we ensure that all subsystems that share a host get initialized even if they do not run a specific connect call.  [reply] Comment 4 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-03 03:36:40 EDT Thanks for explaining the problem, I will try to come up with a patch soon in order to get the fix into M7.  [reply] Comment 5 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-04 11:16:14 EDT Created attachment 98562 [details] Patch for this bug  SubSystem#resolveFilterString() methods are not called when content assist action is performed. We could check for adapter==null in CommandEntryContentAssistProcessor#getImageFor and load the adapters but this is potentially slow operation and may slow down the CA action. So, my proposal is to place the loadAdapter() call in ShellServiceSubSystem#internalRunShell which is spawned as a job when the user select "Launch Shell".  [reply] Comment 6 Martin Oberhuber 2008-05-05 20:13:25 EDT Hm... loading adapters in the internalRunShell() method is a good idea, but I'm not sure if it actually helps loading the shells.ui adapters here? - My understanding was that the files.ui adapters were missing and led to the NPE, no?  This seems to work currently, because shells.ui has a dependency on files.ui in its MANIFEST.MF, but I'd actually like to get rid of this dependency, see also bug  227535 for the terminal, a similar approach should be there for the shells. It's just not logical that shells.ui depends on files.ui.  I still think that the following is more correct: * At the time a shell (or remote command) is launched, the connectorService will be connected * All subsystems that share the same connectorService (and thus get connected) should be initialized * When initializing a subsystem, UI adapters should be loaded.  Essentially, internalRunShell() is the counterpart to resolveFilterString() in files.ui, it needs to start subsystem initialization, and needs to do so for itself as well as all other subsystems on the same connector service.  [reply] Comment 7 Martin Oberhuber 2008-05-05 20:16:00 EDT The other option is living with a slight delay on the content assist, and putting a Platform.getAdapterManager().loadAdapter() call into the method that NPE's because of the missing adapter.  I'm also OK with that solution, at least for now, since the content assist takes a little time anyways, and with the lazy loadAdapter() we get the smallest number of plugins activated.  [reply] Comment 8 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-06 06:30:24 EDT (In reply to comment #6) > Hm... loading adapters in the internalRunShell() method is a good idea, but I'm > not sure if it actually helps loading the shells.ui adapters here? - My > understanding was that the files.ui adapters were missing and led to the NPE, > no? >  I am loading files.ui adapters by requesting an adapter for RemoteFileEmpty. Why do you think I am trying to load shells.ui adapters? Or I am missing something?  > This seems to work currently, because shells.ui has a dependency on files.ui in > its MANIFEST.MF, but I'd actually like to get rid of this dependency, see also > bug  227535 for the terminal, a similar approach should be there for the > shells. It's just not logical that shells.ui depends on files.ui. >  There are 3 classes from files.ui that are used in shells.ui/SystemViewRemoteOutputAdapter, so the dependency on files.ui is very weak and I think it can be easily removed. Feel free to open a bug for this.  > I still think that the following is more correct: >   * At the time a shell (or remote command) is launched, the connectorService >     will be connected >   * All subsystems that share the same connectorService (and thus get > connected) >     should be initialized >   * When initializing a subsystem, UI adapters should be loaded. > > Essentially, internalRunShell() is the counterpart to resolveFilterString() in > files.ui, it needs to start subsystem initialization, and needs to do so for > itself as well as all other subsystems on the same connector service. >  I tend to agree, however I won't have time to perpare and test this for M7.  [reply] Comment 9 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-06 06:45:10 EDT Created attachment 98788 [details] Patch for this bug  Loading the adapters before the NPE is thrown. It turns out that it doesn't slow down a lot the CA action and the patch is simple enough to be included in M7. For the long turn we should consider Martin's algorithm for loading adapters in comment 6. Martin, please review, I am waiting your approval to commit the patch.  [reply] Comment 10 Martin Oberhuber 2008-05-06 07:00:55 EDT (In reply to comment #8) > I am loading files.ui adapters by requesting an adapter for RemoteFileEmpty. > Why do you think I am trying to load shells.ui adapters? Or I am missing  Sorry. Must have been too late for me yesterday. You're right of course.  New patch looks good though I think it can be simplified since we usually don't want really want the RemoteFileEmpty adapter:  // load org.eclipse.rse.files.ui for adapters in order to be able // to perform "content assist" in a local shell, see bug#229956  ISystemViewElementAdapter adapter = (ISystemViewElementAdapter) ((IAdaptable) object).getAdapter(ISystemViewElementAdapter.class); if (adapter == null) { adapter = (ISystemViewElementAdapter) Platform.getAdapterManager().loadAdapter( object, ISystemViewElementAdapter.class.getName()); } descriptor = adapter.getImageDescriptor(object);   When applying this version of the patch, please check the "RemoteOutput" part of your command view after typing ls, pwd and similar commands, whether all operations are possible. It could be that the RemoteOutput also needs some IRemoteFile adapters to display some icons.  On 2nd consideration, your initial patch in launchShell() is perhaps the safer solution, although I'm not overjoyed with it because it does load files.ui a little bit too eagerly (there might be cases where content assist is never used, then files.ui would not be needed). Also, in case a non-UI headless application wants to launch a Shell, it won't ever need any UI so loading the adapters is not adequate in that case.  On the other hand, thanks to lazy adapter loading it's still better than what we had in 2.0 and loading adapters eagerly in launchShell is the safest we can do for now. We can still revise the change later to improve the UI / non-UI story. For now, it's important to stabilize and get the issue fixed.  I'm OK with applying any of your two patches, and revising the situation later when we get rid of the shells.ui --> files.ui dependency (and also shells.core --> files.core if we can). Could you check if there is already a bug for this dependency and create one if not?  [reply] Comment 11 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-06 07:30:46 EDT I committed your version of the patch, I will revise the adapter loading stuff after M7. The remote commands are working fine. Will check if we have a bug for shells.ui -> files.ui and open if we haven't.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [WinCE] Use the progress monitors in WinCEFileService

summary: [files] NPE on canceling copy operation from remote host
description: [files] NPE on canceling copy operation from remote host [reply] Description Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-10 07:37:10 EDT If copy operation from remote host is canceled, the following NPE is thrown:  java.lang.NullPointerException AdapterManager.getAdapter(AdapterManager.java:288) SystemViewRemoteFileAdapter.validateDrop(SystemViewRemoteFileAdapter.java:1546) SystemDNDTransferRunnable.transferRSEResources(SystemDNDTransferRunnable.java:206) SystemDNDTransferRunnable.runInWorkspace(SystemDNDTransferRunnable.java:604) InternalWorkspaceJob.run(InternalWorkspaceJob.java:38) Worker.run(Worker.java:55)  It can be reproduced for both SSH and WinCE (haven't tried with other subsystems). I also wonder why do we display an error dialog when some operation is canceled (see the attached file). I think this is causing bad user experience.  [reply] Comment 1 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-10 07:38:32 EDT Created attachment 99604 [details] Error displayed after cancel  [reply] Comment 2 Martin Oberhuber 2008-05-19 05:03:39 EDT Maybe related due to lazy plugin activation, see bug 218304.  If we trap into an NPE, it's natural to show the error dialog. We shouldn't NPE. Rado do you think you can deal with this? You can SearchCVS for [218304] to find the list of fixes how the adapter loading issue was resolved in various cases.  [reply] Comment 3 Martin Oberhuber 2008-05-20 18:19:06 EDT Bulk update of target milestone  [reply] Comment 4 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-22 05:29:47 EDT I will try to fix this for RC2.  [reply] Comment 5 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-05-28 04:53:59 EDT The problem is not related with lazy plugin activation. When the operation is canceled we got an empty temporary set which we try to validate and we got NPE. The error dialog is shown _before_ the NPE because the SystemOperationCancelledException is treated as error in UniversalFileTransferUtility#downloadFileToWorkspace(). I will need more time to understand the logic behind the transfer operation and to come up with clear solution for this bug.  [reply] Comment 6 Martin Oberhuber 2008-09-30 09:03:12 EDT Rado when do you think you could work on this? Can you update the target milestone please?  [reply] Comment 7 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-09-30 09:11:28 EDT Setting target milestone to 3.0.2. I will be back working actively on RSE in the end of October. So hopefully this will be fixed in 3.0.2.  [reply] Comment 8 Martin Oberhuber 2008-09-30 09:19:38 EDT Hm... do we really need this in the maintenance branch?  Given that we have 2 branches now, I'd like to reserve the maintenance branch for hi-priority / severe / product-required fixes only, and do all normal work in the 3.1 HEAD branch.  [reply] Comment 9 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-09-30 09:25:38 EDT OK, changing to 3.1M3 then.  [reply] Comment 10 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-11-06 11:13:15 EST Created attachment 117218 [details] patch for this bug  The problem occurs when you try to copy files from one host to another. It is two-step process: 1) the files are downloaded from the source host to the workspace 2) the files are uploaded to the destination host from the workspace If you hit "cancel" during the first operation, an error message is shown and NPE is thrown. The proposed patch adds catch clause for SystemOperationCancelledException in downloadFileToWorkspace() in order to prevent showing an error and it makes additional checks on the progress monitor for terminating the whole operation if it is canceled by the user. Note that if there are some downloaded files before the operation is canceled, they are simply discarded because step 2) is skipped. If this behaviour is ok, the patch sould be fine.  [reply] Comment 11 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-11-26 09:06:28 EST Updating the target milestone to 3.1M4 I need someone to review the patch or at least share some thoughts about.  [reply] Comment 12 Martin Oberhuber 2008-11-26 09:10:38 EST I'm fine with the patch, but DaveM should review too because it's his code.  [reply] Comment 13 David McKnight 2008-11-27 10:08:09 EST (In reply to comment #12) > I'm fine with the patch, but DaveM should review too because it's his code. >  That patch looks fine to me.  [reply] Comment 14 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-11-27 10:20:49 EST Thanks Dave, the patch is committed.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [WinCE][api] Implement IRAPISession#CeRapiInvoke
description: [WinCE][api] Implement IRAPISession#CeRapiInvoke [reply] Description Radoslav Gerganov 2008-06-27 08:14:42 EDT The IRAPISession interface contains method CeRapiInvoke which provides general-purpose mechanism for executing routines on the remote device which are loaded from a specified dll (see the bug's URL for more detailed info). This way one could implement any functionality which is not provided by RAPI and invoke it using this API. Speaking about RSE, this will enable the implementation of processes subsystem for WinCE because there are no APIs for process management in the standard RAPI. So we could implement a WinCE DLL having routines for listing the processes, terminating a process, etc., provision this DLL on the device and invoke it's routines via CeRapiInvoke. What do you think about this concept? I have almost complete implentation which works on variety of devices and I would like to submit it for review.  [reply] Comment 1 Martin Oberhuber 2008-06-27 08:19:12 EDT Sounds good!  Looks like you'll need some bootstrapping (copy the helper dll to the device), which can happen manually outside Eclipse or inside RSE. Manually is safer, inside Eclipse is more convenient.  I guess my main concern is that in case the helper DLL is not 100% compatible with a particular device, executing such native code could potentially break the device. Any ideas how to avoid this? My only idea now is to force user to manually install the helper DLL on the device, so it is clear to the user that he is acting on his own responsibility.  RSE could then detect availability of the helper dll, and if it's needed for some functionality but not there, then instruct the user how to install it on the device (perhaps some setup wizard could guide the user in installation, perhaps even copy it to the device, associated with some text that explains potential issues).  [reply] Comment 2 Martin Oberhuber 2008-06-27 08:21:01 EDT Also, consider versioning issues:  Assume that RSE 3.0.1 has installed helper.dll on the remote, then RSE 3.4 (for instance) tries to call stuff with CeRapiInvoke ... correct version of the helper dll on the remote must be checked.  I suggest implementing ONE function like getDllVersion() in the helper DLL, calling this function can then act for detecting availability of the DLL on the remote as well as correct version. Version numbering scheme should be like in Eclipse (major.minor.service.qualifier).  [reply] Comment 3 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-06-27 10:08:35 EDT (In reply to comment #1) > Sounds good! > > Looks like you'll need some bootstrapping (copy the helper dll to the device), > which can happen manually outside Eclipse or inside RSE. Manually is safer, > inside Eclipse is more convenient. > I prefer the manual install because this way the user will be more aware of what is going on. Note that we may want to provide CAB file containing the DLL for installation on the device because this way we can also satisfy the security requirements for some of the devices (see the last part of Remarks section in MSDN).  > I guess my main concern is that in case the helper DLL is not 100% compatible > with a particular device, executing such native code could potentially break > the device. Any ideas how to avoid this? My only idea now is to force user to > manually install the helper DLL on the device, so it is clear to the user that > he is acting on his own responsibility. > I am going to use standard APIs for process management which are available since the first versions of Windows CE. What do you mean by "not 100% compatible"? Even if these API are not available on some device for some reasons we are not going break anything, it just won't work. I agree that the user will be responsible for his actions, that's why I prefer the manual install of the helper dll.  > RSE could then detect availability of the helper dll, and if it's needed for > some functionality but not there, then instruct the user how to install it on > the device (perhaps some setup wizard could guide the user in installation, > perhaps even copy it to the device, associated with some text that explains > potential issues). > Yes, this could be part of the connection wizard for WinCE which needs to be changed anyway (bug 231431). For now I think that downloading the DLL/CAB from the TM site and installing it manually will be OK.  (In reply to comment #2) > Also, consider versioning issues:  Good point, I like the idea of having getDllVersion() to solve this.  [reply] Comment 4 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-06-27 10:49:22 EDT Created attachment 106014 [details] Implementation of CeRapiInvoke  Java wrapper for CeRapiInvoke using block mode for transferring data between the device and the desktop (i.e. the data is transfarred as byte arrays). Once the patch is approved I will also commit the modified jrapi.dll. Martin, please review when you get a chance.  [reply] Comment 5 Martin Oberhuber 2008-06-30 05:03:07 EDT I reviewed your code and it looks good overall. The separation between CeRapiInvoke (for running) and CeRapiInvokeEx (for getting output data) seems a little bit odd, but I assume that this is required by how the RAPI works.  In CeRapiInvoke(), is it ok to env->ReleaseIntArrayElements when the int array is really meant as an output parameter (returning the size and pointer to output data, if I'm not mistaken)?  [reply] Comment 6 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-06-30 05:26:33 EDT (In reply to comment #5) > I reviewed your code and it looks good overall. The separation between > CeRapiInvoke (for running) and CeRapiInvokeEx (for getting output data) seems a > little bit odd, but I assume that this is required by how the RAPI works. >  The separation is needed because there is no easy way to return both the result code of CeRapiInvoke and the output data.  > In CeRapiInvoke(), is it ok to env->ReleaseIntArrayElements when the int array > is really meant as an output parameter (returning the size and pointer to > output data, if I'm not mistaken)? >  Yes, each call to GetIntArrayElements must have corresponding ReleaseIntArrayElements. When you call GetIntArrayElements the JNI will either "pin" down the array or it will make a copy of it into a nonmovable memory. ReleaseIntArrayElements respectively "unpin" the array or copies back the content.  [reply] Comment 7 Martin Oberhuber 2008-06-30 05:49:01 EDT Well, fine then, let's go for it. Note that the version of the RAPI plugin must be incremented from 0.1.0 to 0.2.0 since this is a compatible API change -- I can do that for you once the stuff is committed, since getting all the feature versions right can be a bit tricky.  Since WinCE and RAPI are still in Incubation, I have no problem with doing an API addition in the TM 3.0.x maintenance Stream. Adopters who are writing code against the RAPI Lib know that it's in incubation so they are prepared for ongoing changes. But we should discuss this at the Wednesday TM meeting.  [reply] Comment 8 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-06-30 07:14:26 EDT Patch committed along with the new version of jrapi.dll. The plug-in version is unchanged.  [reply] Comment 9 Radoslav Gerganov 2008-06-30 07:17:07 EDT marking as FIXED  [reply] Comment 10 Martin Oberhuber 2008-06-30 10:48:10 EDT Created attachment 106122 [details] Patch reving up version numbers  Attached patch revs up the CE version numbers from 0.1.0 to 0.2.0  Note that when the new invoke() API is actually used by any of the WinCE code, the "require...;bundle-version=" must be updated from [0.1.0,1.0.0) to [0.2.0,1.0.0)  [reply] Comment 11 Martin Oberhuber 2008-06-30 10:49:30 EDT Committed: [238773] Rev up RAPI version numbers  The change is not yet released for TM 3.0.1 since we need to discuss whether we actually want to release this or keep it in HEAD only for now.  [reply] Comment 12 Martin Oberhuber 2008-07-02 13:34:48 EDT Although this is in HEAD, we won't release it for 3.0.1  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: Wrong path for Process Usage
description: Wrong path for Process Usage [reply] Description wang jun 2008-07-03 23:54:15 EDT EPF 1.5 build 20080702-1845 Steps: 1. New a task and add to an Activity 2. Browse the task, and check path of "Process Usage" -->Expect result: Capability Pattern  >  Phase  >  Iteration  >  Activity  >  New Task  -->Actual result: Activity  >  Capability Pattern  >  Iteration  >  Phase  >  New Task  [reply] Comment 1 Weiping Lu 2008-08-15 21:55:53 EDT Gumin, can you take a look? Looks like the order gets sorted in xsl. This is a regression from epf1.2. If I copy all xsl files from epf1.2 to epf1.5, it works fine.  [reply] Comment 2 Weiping Lu 2008-08-15 21:57:25 EDT I think, fixing 244229 would also fix this bug.  [reply] Comment 3 Ming Gu 2008-08-17 04:07:23 EDT Created attachment 110158 [details] patch for bug239544  Weiping, this issue is different from bug 244229. The elements' order in each path should not be sorted in xsl, but the elements of each path are in ?＜Element?＼ not in ?＜referenceList?＼, and there is no ?＜sortValue?＼ in the path Element. Actually, there is a referenceList contains many path Elements, and each path Element contains some path node Elements, we sort the path in alphabetic order, but do not sort the nodes in each path.  [reply] Comment 4 Weiping Lu 2008-08-18 13:45:01 EDT Gumin, you are right, this is not related to 244229, even though it's a sort issue in xsl. The patch has been applied. Could you double check the fix would not introdue another regression. I noticed that path sort was introduced in 05/28/08 by a patch applied for xiang dong. Thanks.  [reply] Comment 5 Ming Gu 2008-08-18 22:42:41 EDT Checked, all the "Process Usage" sections are correct. And for the patch in 05/28/08, it is my bad, I did not notice that the process usage list is a chain order, and sorted the element node directly.  [reply] Comment 6 wang jun 2008-08-19 11:18:21 EDT Verified on EPF 1.5 build 20080818-1653.  The Prcess Usage path is shown correctly for Task/Role/WPs when then are added to an Activity element. summary: Can't import Microemu 2.0.3 snapshot 37
description: Can't import Microemu 2.0.3 snapshot 37 [reply] Description Craig Setera 2008-08-03 18:11:19 EDT Given that the new approach to using microemu is to use the latest 2.0.3 version with the appropriate skeletons, I tried to do that today.  I downloaded the latest snapshot (as of August 2nd), but the device import logic is unable to locate the SDK.  [reply] Comment 1 Diego Madruga Sandin 2008-08-04 09:14:00 EDT Hi Craig  I've downloaded the latest snapshot from Microemulator from http://snapshot.microemu.org/microemulator/download/ :  build version = 2.0.3-SNAPSHOT build Num = 37  and decompressed it on the FS.  In the import wizard I pointed to the microemu SDK home folder and could successfully import it on both Windows XP (SP 2) and Mac OS X (10.5.4)  Can you give more detains on how i can reproduce the issue you've found?  Thanks, Diego  [reply] Comment 2 Gustavo de Paula 2008-08-26 11:43:43 EDT hi craig,  i was able to reproduce the problem on ubuntu and on eclipse 3.4. it works ok on other environments.  i raised the priority / severity of this bug to make sure we get it fix on 0.9  :) gep   [reply] Comment 3 Craig Setera 2008-08-26 11:49:24 EDT Gustavo,  I'm not thrilled to hear we have a bug, but I'm really happy I'm not the only one seeing it.  Let me know if I can be of any help.  I will say that when I saw the issue it *seemed* like I was seeing the devices flash up in the dialog box and then disappear.  It may be that the import list is somehow getting cleared?  [reply] Comment 4 Gustavo de Paula 2008-08-26 11:55:58 EDT i was also happy to be able to reproduce it :) i hate bugs that are hard to reproduce.  this one almost is a little strange, because on the first time that i run it on ubuntu+eclipse 3.4 MTJ found microemu. but from the second time on, i had to press "refrash" several times. i'm note sure if it always find microemu on the first time and fails only from the second time on. it is also strange that it only fails in eclipse 3.4 + ubuntu. maybe it is also failing in other environments but we were not able to identify yet  i haven't debugged the code yet (still trying to catch up everything from the last weeks on MTJ)  let us just make sure it get fix for 0.9  :) gep   (In reply to comment #3) > Gustavo, > > I'm not thrilled to hear we have a bug, but I'm really happy I'm not the only > one seeing it.  Let me know if I can be of any help.  I will say that when I > saw the issue it *seemed* like I was seeing the devices flash up in the dialog > box and then disappear.  It may be that the import list is somehow getting > cleared? >   [reply] Comment 5 Craig Setera 2008-08-31 20:45:24 EDT I managed to track this one down.  It turned out that I was using asyncExec in the device import wizard page when it should have been syncExec.  This caused the order of import and list clearing to be indeterminate.  It is strange that it only seemed to show up on Ubuntu with Microemu, but given the location of the problem it could have shown up on any platform for any emulator import.  I've checked in the fixed for this in DeviceImportWizard page.  Please review the change and make sure it look ok.  [reply] Comment 6 Gustavo de Paula 2008-10-15 09:22:01 EDT all bugs we integrated and release on MTj 0.9  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: Richtext: Asynchronous event handling on linux does not check "isDisposed"
description: Richtext: Asynchronous event handling on linux does not check "isDisposed" [reply] Description Alex Fitzpatrick 2008-09-11 17:11:20 EDT Build ID: 1.2.0.v20080609-1005  Steps To Reproduce: When quickly switching between editors it is possible that not all events have finished before the widget is disposed. This results in the following error:  !ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 4 0 2008-09-11 16:46:07.589 !MESSAGE Unhandled event loop exception !STACK 0 org.eclipse.swt.SWTException: Failed to execute runnable (org.eclipse.swt.SWTException: Widget is disposed) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3777) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3695) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Synchronizer.runAsyncMessages(Synchronizer.java:136) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runAsyncMessages(Display.java:3378) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:3036) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java:2382) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runUI(Workbench.java:2346) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.access$4(Workbench.java:2198) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench$5.run(Workbench.java:493) at org.eclipse.core.databinding.observable.Realm.runWithDefault(Realm.java:288) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.createAndRunWorkbench(Workbench.java:488) at org.eclipse.ui.PlatformUI.createAndRunWorkbench(PlatformUI.java:149) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.ide.application.IDEApplication.start(IDEApplication.java:113) at org.eclipse.equinox.internal.app.EclipseAppHandle.run(EclipseAppHandle.java:193) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.runApplication(EclipseAppLauncher.java:110) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.internal.adaptor.EclipseAppLauncher.start(EclipseAppLauncher.java:79) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:382) at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run(EclipseStarter.java:179) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method) at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:45) at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:37) at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:599) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.invokeFramework(Main.java:549) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:504) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:1236) at org.eclipse.equinox.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:1212) Caused by: org.eclipse.swt.SWTException: Widget is disposed at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3777) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3695) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3666) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.error(Widget.java:446) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Widget.checkWidget(Widget.java:384) at org.eclipse.swt.browser.Browser.execute(Browser.java:401) at org.eclipse.epf.richtext.RichText$1.run(RichText.java:631) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.RunnableLock.run(RunnableLock.java:35) at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Synchronizer.runAsyncMessages(Synchronizer.java:133) ... 23 more  More information: Patch provided  [reply] Comment 1 Alex Fitzpatrick 2008-09-11 17:12:45 EDT Created attachment 112356 [details] Patch to check if the widget is disposed while executing javascript commands asynchronously  [reply] Comment 2 Bingxue Xu 2008-09-12 01:19:34 EDT please review and verify.  [reply] Comment 3 Bingxue Xu 2008-09-12 01:21:31 EDT Is this fix needed in 1.2.0.3, or 1.2.0.4,or 1.5.x?  [reply] Comment 4 Xiao Dan Xia 2008-09-12 05:01:58 EDT I can't reproduce this problem. But theoretically, it's possible.  The patch seems ok. But I think it needs to consider synchronization issue.  Suppose below scenario:  .... <1>  if (!isDisposed()) { <2>	editor.execute(script); } ...  1. thread 1 execute <1> and isDisposed() return false 2. thread 2 disposes the editor 3. now thread 1 shouldn't execute <2>, but because there's no synchronization mechanism, thread 1 continue to execute <2>, and might still get the error exception  ========== So I think the patch might look like this:  synchronized(editor){ <1>  if (!isDisposed()) { <2>	editor.execute(script); } }  [reply] Comment 5 Alex Fitzpatrick 2008-09-12 10:11:59 EDT We are currently using 1.2.0.4 (which bugzilla will not let me specify BTW) but we are considering moving up to 1.5.  I would suggest you fix it in both if that's not a problem.  [reply] Comment 6 Alex Fitzpatrick 2008-09-12 10:37:12 EDT I don't think the synchronization is necessary as that asynch exec will always cause that code to execute in the UI thread.  However, I don't see how it could hurt either other than adding a slight overhead to each command executed on Linux.  [reply] Comment 7 Jeff Hardy 2008-09-16 18:20:23 EDT Patch applied to EPF 1.5.0.1 stream, please resolve.  [reply] Comment 8 Xiao Dan Xia 2008-09-17 20:32:35 EDT solution is reviewed and works.  [reply] Comment 9 Xue Dong Mei 2008-10-28 05:58:42 EDT Verified in Redhat 5 Update 2 and fixed.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: Remove Tomcat references from documentation
description: Remove Tomcat references from documentation [reply] Description David Whiteman 2008-10-10 16:34:02 EDT The documentation needs to be scrubbed of references to Tomcat, since prereqing or implying that it's a prereq, is not legally approved by Eclipse IP.  Please compile a list of Tomcat references in the docs, and work with developers to determine the appropriate wording change.  In many cases, you can refer to a "web server that supports JSP and Servlet technology" in lieu of Tomcat.  References to example command line invocations that include references to Tomcat, such as c:\tomcat-5-5-25, should be changed to something like c:\web-server-5-5-25 or just <web-server-directory>.  These changes must be done before we ship version 1.0.  [reply] Comment 1 SrinivasReddy 2008-10-14 02:13:56 EDT By removing tomcat references from all docs, how does an end user know which webserver to use and also which version to use ? So that would be something we would want to target for the future.  But in the near term we should remove any references to Tomcat in the docs or Wiki, since we need to be in good shape with that for our release review.  Please bring this issue up at the comm call tomorrow if you want to discuss this directly with Ruth. summary: [fiximprove]:  Sun Wireless Toolkit 3.0 EA does not support MIDlet class on command-line
description: [fiximprove]:  Sun Wireless Toolkit 3.0 EA does not support MIDlet class on command-line [reply] Description Craig Setera 2008-10-19 15:28:20 EDT The current Sun UEI handling appends the target MIDlet class name to the command-line to specify which MIDlet of a suite should be launched.  The new 3.0 early access version will now fail to launch with the MIDlet class appended to the command-line.  I will be checking in a new UEI device properties file that allows the emulator to be launched for this version.  It is likely some thought needs to be given to launching in three different modes: - JAD - Midlet Suite Project - Individual midlet  Certain emulators may not support all of these options... at least not directly.  [reply] Comment 1 Craig Setera 2008-10-19 17:59:48 EDT Checked in a new UEI device properties file that has an entry for the 3.0 version of the WTK.  This version does not include the target class on the command line when launching.  [reply] Comment 2 Gustavo de Paula 2008-12-30 14:10:34 EST bug released into 0.9.1  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: Convert Action Bar Contributors to org.eclipse.ui.menus extension point
description: Convert Action Bar Contributors to org.eclipse.ui.menus extension point [reply] Description David Carver 2008-10-20 18:30:06 EDT The Document and other actionbar handlers should be converted to the new org.eclipse.ui.menus extension point and command handlers.   The reason being is that this is more RCP friendly and also more adopter friendly.  It allows for easier contribution by others to the menus, and handling of the the various commands.
