summary: [BinStorage] Concept Discussion
description: [BinStorage] Concept Discussion [reply] Description thomas menzel 2008-10-21 10:49:29 EDT this bug shall make the discussion in regard to the concept open and transparent and thus avoid spamming the dev-list.  [reply] Comment 1 thomas menzel 2008-10-21 11:51:15 EDT # Storage Mechanism Internal Structure > Object Database why an object database? wouldnt any database do that supports BLOBs? and also: most those named ODBs are GPL and hence not fir for Eclipse usage.  > hierarchical structure i guess what u described here is a B-Tree algorithm if i understood it correctly. i suppose u should be able to find sources and maybe even implementations on that on the internet but i haven't checked that.  as to the storing of the mapping: i dont think that this is needed when u deterministically calculate the node position from the ID.  > concurrent access/cluster i would, if possible, delegate this to the underlying implementation.  clustering is similar to the XmlStorage, where BDB supports clustering under a write-master/slave readers scenario which might be a good choice here too. in that case we should make that choice/re-election of a new master instance in a distributed scenario transparent to any client.  > use of VFS would u limit its use to the already implemented/available technologies? or differently asked: as far as i can see, VFS doenst support DB storage yet. when supporting that, would make an impl for VFS to support it or rather an impl. against te BinStorageService Interface?     [reply] Comment 2 Marius Cimpean 2008-10-21 15:19:21 EDT (In reply to comment #1) > # Storage Mechanism Internal Structure > > Object Database > why an object database? wouldnt any database do that supports BLOBs? > and also: most those named ODBs are GPL and hence not fir for Eclipse usage.  [marius] we need something capable to store binary data (blobs). Also RDBMS are capable to do that...but we don't use anything else from it, like querying. RDBMSs have been built based on central server architectures. Also, the RDBMSs typically limit all processing to the SQL language and its operations (SELECT/PROJECT/JOIN and INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE). ODBMSs simply use the object language to create and access objects.... so, in conclusion we may also use RDBMS if required  > > hierarchical structure > i guess what u described here is a B-Tree algorithm if i understood it > correctly. i suppose u should be able to find sources and maybe even > implementations on that on the internet but i haven't checked that.  [marius] basically b-trees are fundamental data structure used to construct other data (more abstract) structures with the major advantage of binary search, sorting or traversing. Through this hierarchic structure I did not refer to a b-tree. Also,in this hierarchic structure I don't use the parent - child terms (relation, nodes) to determine a record (leaf).  > as to the storing of the mapping: i dont think that this is needed when u > deterministically calculate the node position from the ID.  [marius] yes, right. This is also possible. but this is very dependent on the hash algorithm...I just indexed 21.000 files and took a look into the binary storage. The records naming is different starting with the 2nd or the 3rd char. i.e. faa8d9d1f71e5f3a1b7d8a557e36f12546cc7556eccdbbf517cb1b0206d, fa45682267968e0066a9ac89fb8ce3b49b8e48585b7cca886e7484f3b9 Of course, we can deterministically calculate a node position (path) but it may be that we end up with lot of records in the same folder (path) like current impl.  > > concurrent access/cluster > i would, if possible, delegate this to the underlying implementation. > clustering is similar to the XmlStorage, where BDB supports clustering under a > write-master/slave readers scenario which might be a good choice here too. in > that case we should make that choice/re-election of a new master instance in a > distributed scenario transparent to any client.  [marius] right. this would be the ideal solution.  > > use of VFS > would u limit its use to the already implemented/available technologies? > or differently asked: as far as i can see, VFS doenst support DB storage yet. > when supporting that, would make an impl for VFS to support it or rather an > impl. against te BinStorageService Interface?  [marius] ther will be a configuration part (a imple xml file... or something like that). If user doesn't configure anything a default implementation will be used. Only one of the persistence options impl. (File System - local hard drive - Flat or hierarchical structure/ Distributed file system ... Object DataBase) will be used by the BinaryStorage Service at a time (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/SMILA/Project_Concepts/Binary_Storage#UML_Class_Diagram)  [reply] Comment 3 Marius Cimpean 2008-10-22 02:19:48 EDT > > as to the storing of the mapping: i dont think that this is needed when u > > deterministically calculate the node position from the ID.  [marius] Also, currently the only client of Binary Storage Service (BSS) is the blackboard - which generates the id (hashed) by itself. In case that the BSS shall deterministically calculate the node position from the ID, BSS shall generate by itself the hashed-IDs to be used in deterministically calculation, even for IDs passed from blackboard.  blackboard (generates ID) ---> call BSS  --> BSS (generates hashed ID &process)  client component(uses some key)  ---> call BSS  --> BSS (generates hashed ID &process)   [reply] Comment 4 Daniel Stucky 2008-10-22 04:34:21 EDT Some more comments.  - Hierarchical structure: Igor has had the idea to make use of the fact that the key is a hash-key. Instead of complex computing the node position on could use the hashkey to create the path to the node, by splitting it in N parts und use the hash-key itself as filename. E.g. heash-key is "faa8d9d1f71e" then the path could be fa/a8/d9/d1/f7/1e/faa8d9d1f71e. The distribution then depends on the randomness of the hash algorithm used to create the key. This could be a simple alternative. A drawback I see is, that one cannot enforce that the key parameter is a reasonable hash (e.g. when used by other developers.  - Object DataBase: I agree with Tom that RDBMS should be supported, too  - Cluster configuration: Is there a need the set flat/hierachical structure on top of a DFS? Doesn't a DFS decide by itself where it stores it's files ?  - Technical aspects: please don't restrict to Commons VSF only. At the moment we have massive memory problems using VFS. So please also consider alternatives (like http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/EFS).  [reply] Comment 5 Marius Cimpean 2008-10-22 07:06:04 EDT (In reply to comment #4) > Some more comments. > - Hierarchical structure: Igor has had the idea to make use of the fact that > the key is a hash-key. Instead of complex computing the node position on could > use the hashkey to create the path to the node, by splitting it in N parts und > use the hash-key itself as filename. E.g. heash-key is "faa8d9d1f71e" then the > path could be fa/a8/d9/d1/f7/1e/faa8d9d1f71e. The distribution then depends on > the randomness of the hash algorithm used to create the key. This could be a > simple alternative. A drawback I see is, that one cannot enforce that the key > parameter is a reasonable hash (e.g. when used by other developers.  [marius] this may be a solution also. but just imagine that for each record BSS will create 6 folders and it is very possible to have a matching name only for the first two or three folder names (like fa/a8).  > - Object DataBase: I agree with Tom that RDBMS should be supported, too  [marius] good. I'll update the concept page  > - Cluster configuration: Is there a need the set flat/hierachical structure on > top of a DFS? Doesn't a DFS decide by itself where it stores it's files ?  [marius] at least following parameters shall be provided/configured : "sftp://user:pass@HOST/root"  > - Technical aspects: please don't restrict to Commons VSF only. At the moment > we have massive memory problems using VFS. So please also consider alternatives > (like http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/EFS).  [marius] Right. since we still have some memory issues with commons-vfs.  [reply] Comment 6 Daniel Stucky 2008-10-22 09:57:53 EDT In conjunction with DFS (Distributed File System) you mentioned FTP and SFTP. What were your thoughts behind them ? These are just protocols.  [reply] Comment 7 Marius Cimpean 2008-10-22 10:34:58 EDT yes, right. these are protocols that most file-system APIs provide implementations for in order to access the distributed fs (like commons-vfs or EFS).  [reply] Comment 8 thomas menzel 2008-10-23 06:26:29 EDT (In reply to comment #2) > > > use of VFS > > would u limit its use to the already implemented/available technologies? > > or differently asked: as far as i can see, VFS doenst support DB storage yet. > > when supporting that, would make an impl for VFS to support it or rather an > > impl. against te BinStorageService Interface? > > [marius] ther will be a configuration part (a imple xml file... or something > like that). If user doesn't configure anything a default implementation will be > used. Only one of the persistence options impl. (File System - local hard drive   u didnt quite answer my question. it was in regard to the class diagram and how we would implement storage technologies that are not yet supported by VFS.  [reply] Comment 9 Marius Cimpean 2008-10-28 06:40:59 EDT The Binary Storage Service will not extend the commons-vfs to provide all concrete implementations (like RDBMS or ODBMS). Main reasons would be: - not make our BSS implementation dependent on the commons-vfs. - commons-vfs is a strictly file-system API. To extend the commons-vfs for other implementation, like RDBMS we should take care of some technical considerations (specific for RDBMS - like transactions & ACID operations & isolations level ...) which are not supported by commons-vfs; - in case we will switch from commons-vfs to another API, the we will have to move our extensions too.  [reply] Comment 10 thomas menzel 2008-10-29 04:44:59 EDT all VFS and its implementation related details/problems should be discussed now @ bug 252353. thus, this bug is more concerned about the conceptual aspects of the binstorage.  question in regard to configurable tree: how, or more precisely WHERE do u intend to safe the mapping information? it cant be in memory due to the possible amount of files!  i also dont like the idea of saving mapping data conceptually. i understand that a B-Tree will cause some overhead in calculating the deterministic path and also when it needs to reorganize the nodes to fit it's configuration but i think this is not such a big problem if the node sizes have a fairly large range, e.g. 256..512.  besides, moving files in a local file system isnt that costly. when dealing with distributed storage (in the sense if FTP) one needs to become careful though to avoid moving files between nodes, especially when managing different storage nodes in the cluster as part of the B-TREE . This also applies to the local FS when it spans different partitions.   [reply] Comment 11 Marius Cimpean 2008-10-29 05:09:30 EDT  > how, or more precisely WHERE do u intend to safe the mapping information? it cant be in memory due to the possible amount of files!  Mappings could be save also in the file-system (into a separate virtual system)...or using a simple ODBMS...not decided yet  [reply] Comment 12 Juergen Schumacher 2008-10-29 08:14:22 EDT I'm not in favor of using a mandatory database system in a file system oriented binstorage. It introduces either adminsitrative overhead or scalability issues. If additional mapping info needs to be stored, it should be done in the same file system. Or even better, IMHO it should be avoided completely (-;  [reply] Comment 13 thomas menzel 2009-06-19 08:26:00 EDT closing this out as it has been setteled for now.  [reply] Comment 14 Andreas Weber 2013-04-15 11:31:02 EDT Closing this  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: AccProbe: When global tracking, tree view doesn't update when focus changes
description: AccProbe: When global tracking, tree view doesn't update when focus changes [reply] Description Pete Brunet 2008-10-21 18:18:42 EDT Enable global tracking.  The tree view should update to show the currently focused object as the user tabs from control to control.  [reply] Comment 1 Mike 2008-10-22 10:38:45 EDT Kavitha - you can use the task-switching events (that we are currently filtering out of the Event Monitor) to see which top-level window has focus and then select that window in the Explorer View. The remainder of finding the correct node in the view based on kybd focus/mouse cursor should be done as before.  [reply] Comment 2 Kavitha Teegala 2009-02-02 15:29:05 EST Changes committed. I used a different approach to select the right window in Explorer View because using focus to get active window will not always work, especially with mouse cursor tracking. The processId of the accessible object being tracked is compared  with the pid of the selected object in the explorer view. If it's not the same, all the top level windows are scanned for their Pid's and the matching window will be selected and then expanded to show the accessible object.  [reply] Comment 3 Kavitha Teegala 2009-03-06 09:46:56 EST Verified.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [Bin Storage] Implementation :: VFS vs. EFS
description: [Bin Storage] Implementation :: VFS vs. EFS [reply] Description thomas menzel 2008-10-28 09:28:33 EDT Due to some bugs in VFS there has been a notion of maybe replacing this with another implementation, e.g. EFS which fulfills a similar use case.  This bug shall serve as a collector for por and cons to get to come to the decision for choosing one over the other.  here are some resources on the subject: --------------------------------------- http://eclipsezone.com/forums/thread.jspa?messageID=92063570 read the comments for more insight !! http://eclipsezone.com/forums/thread.jspa?messageID=92063570#92063570  https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=106176 look for comments containing VFS to see why they dont use it note worthy: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=106176#c20 on the semantic diff. of FileSystem in VFS and EFS  problem with VFS: ------------------ VFS offers internal support for caching. to this extend it maintains two large maps: one holds (as far as we know so far) the cached binary data while the other holds a map for the listeners to all objects in the files system. listeners are needed to keep the cache in sync in case a 3rd party changes the files in the underlying filesystem and hence all items starting from a node in the plugined in filesystem seem to have a listner.  while it seems that items in the cache can be removed to free up memory (depends on cache strategy) this doesnt seem to be true for the listeners. this is possible a bug but maybe also by design, but marius is looking into that and possible find a way to patch.  in case this is by design, VFS cannot be used for SMILA b/c of the use case to store millions of items in BinStorage which will in that case not be possible due to memory constraints.  [reply] Comment 1 Juergen Schumacher 2008-10-28 12:00:15 EDT I've not yet read the resources about EFS (will do it tomorrow), but in my opinion at least for the initial SMILA version there is a simple third alternative: Do not use any abstract filesystem at all, but implement a simple binstorage that just support (java.io.)Files. We can do a binstorage implentation (or adapt the first version) based on an abstract file system later when we know better about the pros and contras of different implementations. Or is there an advantage of using an abstract filesystem implementation when we currently use only a "real" filesystem for the binary data anyway?  [reply] Comment 2 Marius Cimpean 2008-10-28 12:19:19 EDT Related to EFS - the only thing I am worried about is the old thread/messages list. The community posts are little old (2005, 2006) . Anyway, just in case it will be necessary, research will give us better results related to EFS.  Advantage of using an abstract file system implementation is related to distributed file system (ftp,sftp) - which we will need to use it in next future.  [reply] Comment 3 thomas menzel 2008-10-29 04:12:06 EDT >  the only thing I am worried about is the old thread/messages list. i wouldnt worry about old community posts for EFS b/c it is a working building block in eclipse. so it has support and it seems to work.  > Do not use any abstract filesystem at all, shure, that is always possible. dont see a problem though currently in regard to timeframe  [reply] Comment 4 Marius Cimpean 2008-10-29 05:03:41 EDT (In reply to comment #3) > >  the only thing I am worried about is the old thread/messages list. > i wouldnt worry about old community posts for EFS b/c it is a working building > block in eclipse. so it has support and it seems to work. [marius] as suggested, a EFS research and some tests will give use best answers.  > Do not use any abstract filesystem at all, shure, that is always possible. dont see a problem though currently in regard to timeframe [marius] I already implemented a simple way of storing binary records into the local file system (no abstract filesystem at all). This may be a solution for a period of time too,....but as soon as we need to be able to access (persist/fetch) data into distributed file system I think we will reinvent the wheal. So, for the moment I think it is very important to know if only the local file system is in our scope.  [reply] Comment 5 Juergen Schumacher 2008-10-29 07:36:58 EDT A "local" file system solution does not restrict us to "physically local" file system, we can still use shared network drives or NFS or whatever else can be treated transparently. I'm not sure how relevant something like FTP/SFTP is in this context. Actually I would be even more interested in supporting a real distributed file system (something like Hadoop DFS), but that's not the scope currently.  Regarding "VFS vs EFS": For a real decision we would need an evaluation of the performance of both implementations (I reckon, they both should be able to support the binstorage needs, so that should not be an issue. Or is it?). And in this context it would be interesting to see what overhead they introduced compared to using java.io.File&Co. immediately. If the overhead is significant we could use a "local filesystem" implementation of the BinStorage service anyway for optimal performance, and an additional xFS implementation for cases where the flexibility is important.  And in case that EFS does not have significant worse performance compared to VFS I would vote for using EFS because we are in the Eclipse community anyway, and the development of EFS seems to be more active (at least in the e4-dev-list there is also some talk about EFS) than that of VFS (apparently they do not even care about fixing memory leaks ...)  Cheers, Juergen  [reply] Comment 6 Marius Cimpean 2008-10-29 07:59:28 EDT I agree with you Juergen. I'll soon post some remarks related to VFS. I already started (and have) a java.io.* implementation for our binary storage. I will also go in parallel with some EFS research to see how it behaves.  [reply] Comment 7 Marius Cimpean 2008-10-29 08:38:06 EDT related to the VFS issues:  the two maps that holds instances which commons-vfs works with, are : - cache map - listeners map  The cache map could be earlier released, by removing the cached object after each access (unfortunately there is no way you can setup commons-vfs working without cache).  The listeners map is the main memory consumption and there is no external way (accessing the API) from the client side to deal with it  - this is how was meant to be.  Also, I posted technical questions to the commons-vfs community (forum discussions list & email) but got no answers.  At the moment, from this point of view (memory consumption) we could choose to : - drop of the commons-vfs (at least for the next period of time) and to move forward (even with our java.io implementation or something else - already mentioned in this thread) - patch the commons-vfs & support the commons-vfs project (I don't suggest this option for the moment...)  Based on these facts, it looks like we need to switch from commons-vfs to something else.  If there is anyone who strongly supports usage of commons-vfs (at least for this project phase), please post your arguments.  [reply] Comment 8 thomas menzel 2008-10-29 11:41:50 EDT hi, newest info is that we will upload code soon at eclipse and hence will have a code freeze.  if possible, it be nice to have the Binary Storage Service API fixed and also a working impl. that works for/with local FS.  So plz focus on that.  [reply] Comment 9 Marius Cimpean 2008-10-29 12:18:36 EDT yes. sure  [reply] Comment 10 thomas menzel 2009-06-19 08:27:20 EDT closing this as VFS is no option and mater has been settled  [reply] Comment 11 thomas menzel 2009-06-19 08:29:18 EDT closing this as VFS is no option and mater has been settled  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: VEX Document Menu always active
description: VEX Document Menu always active [reply] Description David Carver 2008-10-29 13:34:25 EDT The VEX Editor's Document contribution is always active even if the editor isn't open.   This should only appear when the editor is opened, and it should be converted to the org.eclipse.ui.menus extension point and command/handler framework instead of action framework.  This will allow easier adopter extension and contributions.  [reply] Comment 1 David Carver 2009-11-09 17:20:22 EST CCing Holger on this as well.  [reply] Comment 2 Holger Voormann 2009-11-22 03:47:55 EST Created attachment 152801 [details] Fix for bug 252628 and bug 251488  Patch includes following changes: - Actions converted to command handlers - Document and context menu contributed via "org.eclipse.ui.menus" (see bug 251488) - Enablement/visibility declaratively managed by "org.eclipse.ui.services" - Naming and placing of menu items aligned with Eclipse UI convention (e.g. in contrast to documents/files which are created with 'New...' and deleted with 'Delete' smaller parts are "Add"ed and "Remove"d; Document and context menu rearranged) - Refactoring to avoid duplicated code (e.g. by introducing some abstract handlers)  Because this patch probably exceeds the 250 lines IP log limit I guess I have to answer the three IP log questions:  > 1.  Did he authored 100% of the content Yes. (as individual)  > 2.  Does he have the rights to donate the content to Eclipse Yes. (I am the only author.)  > 3.  Does he contribute the content under the EPL Yes. (New files contain EPL header.)  [reply] Comment 3 David Carver 2009-11-27 14:57:46 EST This patch looks good.   Because of the size and the fact that committer voting will end later today.  I'm going to hold off on applying the patch for now.   Depending on how quick you get your committer paperwork completed will be a big factor in how quickly we get this included.   The reason to hold off is that I think it will take IP about as long to review the patch as it will to get the paperwork and done and complete.  [reply] Comment 4 David Carver 2009-11-27 14:59:21 EST Oh and in order to test some of this, you may have to create some Mocks so that you can test the functionality of the handlers.  Might also want to go on IRC and ask either remey or paul webb how to go about unit testing these handlers.  [reply] Comment 5 Holger Voormann 2009-11-27 17:05:13 EST (In reply to comment #4) To fix this bug I have not changed any algorithm of an action/handler but moved bigger parts of code to new classes without knowledge of the algorithm in detail. So I like to write UI tests as separate task. Maybe making the Vex widget SWTBot ready could be also an alternative.  [reply] Comment 6 David Carver 2009-12-03 10:49:14 EST Assigning to you Holger since your paper work is now complete.  Welcome aboard and congrats.  Make sure you subscribe to the wtp-incubator-dev mailing list.  [reply] Comment 7 Holger Voormann 2009-12-03 14:44:31 EST Patch applied  [reply] Comment 8 Florian Thienel 2011-06-02 05:20:35 EDT Closing resolved bugs.  [reply] Comment 9 Florian Thienel 2011-11-09 17:36:19 EST Moved to Mylyn Docs Vex.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: Logging/Monitoring Path of Records
description: Logging/Monitoring Path of Records [reply] Description Sebastian Voigt 2008-11-06 10:01:38 EST We need a solution to monitor / Log the path from records that are travel through our framework.  Can Logging with a specifc loggerclass used for this?  I think we need 5 messages 1. record with id was crawled 2. record with id send to queue xy 3. dfp reads record from queue xy 4. dfp send record to queue xy 5. lucene pipelet send record to index  [reply] Comment 1 Dmitry Hazin 2008-11-07 11:22:54 EST Creating logger for every record id won't be a good practice, because when the method LogFactory.getLog(name) is executed, it creates new Logger instance for each name and puts it into internal HashMap. Thus creating Logger for every record id will cause the great memory consumption. Possible solution can be to use the same Logger with some predefined name for all records and put id information into the log message. Log4JLogger adapter from commons logging can be extended so that it will have additional method that will get the 'records' Logger and log messages into it, so the usage will be transparent for the end user, something like _log.info(String message, Id id) or _log.info(String message, String idHash). With this solution records lifecycle information will go to separate logger without forcing user to get this separate logger each time.  [reply] Comment 2 Dmitry Hazin 2008-11-26 11:33:54 EST Logging of the record path through framework was added to the code.  [reply] Comment 3 Andreas Weber 2013-04-15 11:31:59 EDT Closing this  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: Inable to enter valid local file in Mozilla Acccessibility Validation run config
description: Inable to enter valid local file in Mozilla Acccessibility Validation run config [reply] Description Ann Ford 2008-11-10 18:04:30 EST Steps to recreate. 1  Create a new Mozilla Accessibility Validation run configuration 2  Select the Local File option. 3  Select the browse button and browse to an html file somewhere in the C drive. (I used C:\test\accprobe\about.html) and select OK.  The full filename is entered in the Launch target entry field.  However, and error appears on the launch configuration dialog that reads " A valid file must be specified."  [reply] Comment 1 Ann Ford 2008-11-10 18:22:33 EST Additional information - The apply and run buttons are disabled at this point (presumably because of the error) so it appears there is no way to save your choice.  However, if you select to close, a pop-up prompts you to save your changes, and will allow you to do so.  If you then re-open the run configuration, the filename is now prefixed with "file:/" and the error is gone. It appears that this needs to be prepended to the string in order for it to meet the test (i.e. file:/C:/test/accprobe/about.html).  Once this is done, the validation proceeds correctly.  [reply] Comment 2 Mike 2008-11-24 11:33:38 EST pls investigate and probably as simple as Ann's proposed fix.  [reply] Comment 3 Kavitha Teegala 2008-12-15 09:40:53 EST Fix committed. There are the issues I fixed: 1) The atrribute value for ATTR_IS_URL in launch configuartion is always set to be true ireespective of the value for isUrl. So, everytime a saved configuaration is re-opened, the path shows the local file but the URL button is selected. Also, reset the values for ATTR_PROJECT and ATTR_WEB_MODULE attributes in case of a local file. 2) Apply and run buttons are being disabled because the isValidPath() is always returning false for a local file. 3) It looks like updateWidgetEnablements() needs to be called before updateLaunchConfigurationDialog() for the Apply or Run buttons to be enabled.  [reply] Comment 4 Kavitha Teegala 2008-12-15 18:07:58 EST Ted, Please verify and close if satisfied. summary: Webcrawler should JavaScript/Flash into Account
description: Webcrawler should JavaScript/Flash into Account [reply] Description Sebastian Voigt 2008-11-18 03:09:19 EST WebCrawler should support JavaScript & Flash  1) Report what is supported now 2) investigate which solution can be used a) crawl "Javasscript/Flash" references/links b) crawling of  JavaScript/Flash - "content"  [reply] Comment 1 Dmitry Hazin 2008-11-21 05:37:38 EST Created attachment 118450 [details] investigation of javascript and flash support in the webcrawler  [reply] Comment 2 Dmitry Hazin 2008-12-29 09:19:11 EST Javascript parsing: Javascript code is not evaluated currently, just analyzed for possible urls entries (based on regexp matching). Javascript code is analyzed from javascript files (MIME types application/x-javascript and text/javascript), from contents of the <script> DOM element, from href="javascript:..." attributes and from on<something> attributes (like onclick etc).  Flash parsing: Flash parser works for MIME-type application/x-shockwave-flash. swfutils.jar library from Adobe Flex SDK (MPL 1.1 licensed, need to recheck license information) is used for parsing SWF files. Text is extracted from text fields and initial edit text fields. Also text and urls are extracted from ActionScript 1/2 code (version 3 support is not implemented yet). Actionscript code is analyzed in the following way: 1. Urls from geturl action are added to the list of urls; 2. AS virtual machine stack is emulated to some extent to separate variable and function names in the disassembled code from text assignments. Text assignments are analyzed for being urls (with regexp). Text assignments from setMember action are added to the list of extracted text strings.  Need to discuss: 1. Probably parsing of different content types should be done with ProcessingServices rather than by webcrawler itself? 2. The way how extracted text should be returned. Currently text is returned as byte[] which should be html but it won't work for flash content.   [reply] Comment 3 Sebastian Voigt 2009-01-14 05:29:27 EST Regarding Junit-Tests Try to Prepare it that way, that we can test it with the build but have no problems with licencing (that means, we dont should store in subversion material from other pages). I think you can create a small flash, that contains the basic things, that you extract, or you can try to analyze official swfs from known pages (adobe?).  Regarding the Version support, i think we should support also the last version, thus please implement at least basic support for v3.  [reply] Comment 4 Dmitry Hazin 2009-02-09 06:34:47 EST Added junit-test, added avm2 support (extracting urls from ABC String Constant Pool)  [reply] Comment 5 Andreas Weber 2013-04-15 11:32:49 EDT Closing this  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

But what happens to changes of the configuration of an existing index ? I think they should not be effective as long as the index is not deleted manually by a user.  [reply] Comment 11 Sebastian Voigt 2009-01-27 10:08:53 EST Yes i forget the Mappings.xml.  I've to explain my idea a little bit more.   I thought the index were right now created dynamically while crawling, thank you for the information that they are created at startup.  i want to talk here more about the Create index, because until we have a new search implementation the user should not have to create entries manually in the datadictionary. Right now the delete_index command delete entries in the Datadictionary, that means we need some implementation that can create that entries (triggered with a command). That the index and datadictionary were created automatically while crawling was only a special idea, a fallback.  I am not against that the user have to create the index manually (with a command) before he starts crawling (atm i would be better than creating indices automatically at startup/with the crawling).  My Idea was that the entries that are needed for the datadictionary are stored (like indexorder configurations) in files and we can order the framework (with a jmx-command "create_index") to create an index and the datadictionary entries with the information from the file (e.g. create_index test_index.xml and test_index.xml contains the datadictionary information for the index). Ivan has it right now implemented that the create_index -method can be used to send the datadictionary-content remotely (what is also an interesting solution, which we should allow/implement). I forget the Mappings.xml (like i said), do you have both ideas to integrate that information somehow into the idea i described? create_index need information for the datadictionary and for creating/haveing some mappings-information. [reply] Comment 12 Daniel Stucky 2009-01-27 10:42:24 EST For index creation the mapping.xml is not needed, it is needed when a record is indexed (to map record attributes to index fields).  Logically a new index entry in the DataDictionary.xml imples a new index entry in the mapping.xml, otherwise there will be errors when indexing records.  The Service itself needs never to be be restarted, but if the configuration changes it needs to reload the config files. That was meant with "reinitialize".  With OSGi DS it's easily possible to have multiple LuceneIndexServices. However, you want to be able to add indexes dynamically. This means - dynamic service creation of more instances of LuceneIndexService - dynamic creation of pipelines, as each pipeline has to use another service instance - dynamic adaptation of router rules Altogether this is a really BAD idea !!!  Therefore I added the annotation that allows to tell the service which index to use!  So the only question is how are the configuration files updated and when are the indexes created. Personally I like the service to create indexes automatically. SMILA workflow is a set of dependent configurations of many bundles.  I found only one useful application of that api, it allows to backup a part of lucene index gtom gui --  to rename "test_index" to "test_index1" and to create "test_index" again :)  [reply] Comment 15 Sebastian Voigt 2009-01-28 15:31:44 EST current problems with the current implementation: no separation between configation for an index and its current status (delete_index deletes also entry (first approach was that the DataDictionary should always fit to the current status in Lucene and Pipelet creates all indices that are defined in the datadictionary)  Result: The DIndex settings are lost for the user after delete  i suggest the following changes: 1) indices (lucene) are created with create_index or in the addRecord Method( if no index exits) create_index has one parameter: the index_name create_index searchs the DIndex for that name in the DataDictionary and creates an index based on this settings 2) DataDictionary is the configuration file for the user --> delete_index: no changes to the datadictionary --> rename_index: DIndex is renamed ( i think that is ok for the user) this is be done because search needs the settings  [reply] Comment 16 Sebastian Voigt 2009-01-28 15:48:43 EST addition to my last comment/idea: Mappings.xml is also a user configuration file The code will not change it.  [reply] Comment 17 Ivan Churkin 2009-01-29 04:56:27 EST (In reply to comment #15) >    --> rename_index: DIndex is renamed ( i think that is ok for the user) >        this is be done because search needs the settings >  It's strange that sometimes DIndex is changed automatically and sometimes not. It's unclear.  (bwt, maybe it's more correct here to create a copy of DIndex with new name)  [reply] Comment 18 Sebastian Voigt 2009-01-29 05:59:02 EST final Decision for preliminary solution:  1) DataDictionary and Mapping are files that are managed ONLY by the user  2) Lucene Indicies are created dynamically/ on demand - Pipelet should cache somewhere if a lcuene idnex exists (please no checkIndex for every Record) 3) delete Index -- delete Lcuene Index only 4) rename Index --> rename only the Lucene Index (user has to create by its own a DINdex-part in the DataDictionary) 5) createIndex Parameter: Indexname, pipelet will search a DIndex in the Datadictionary and will create a Lucene Index  First Implementation: Datadictionary are only loaded at startup (no changes at runtime)    For further implementations: Ivan suggested that the DIndex is more a Type of Configuration and there will be lists which maps the existing indices to the Index Type (which contains the search /index configuration)   [reply] Comment 19 Sebastian Voigt 2009-01-29 11:26:21 EST Ivan found out, that the datadictionary have to be sychroniuzed always with the existing directories.  Therefore we decided to use the DataDictionary.xml in the workspace folder. It is always updated! If such an Index is created / (manual with create_index) or automatically (when an index is used by the pipelet) the datadictionaryController will search for such settings in the file in the config folder and will create in the datadictionary such index/settings. --> User can setup Settings in the file in the config folder and the datadictionry (which is stored in the workspace) is always updated (like before in anyfinder)  [reply] Comment 20 Ivan Churkin 2009-02-10 08:16:17 EST guess fixed  [reply] Comment 21 Andreas Weber 2013-04-15 11:41:04 EDT Closing this  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [Investigation] Overhead of the Queue with Multiple DFPS
description: [Investigation] Overhead of the Queue with Multiple DFPS [reply] Description Sebastian Voigt 2008-11-20 03:59:18 EST see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=255926  Ivan could you have a look on that problem,  could you make them measurements what overhead is produced with the activemq with multiple dfps:  1) setup a clustering simulation envrinoment, use our servers (see dmitrys 2 nodes page) 2) daniel has made different tests, without activemq (router was executing BPEL processes) and with multpile DFPS (runtime processes for processing, converting html), with multiple DFPS the system was slower (that is weird, because the tasks executed in the router dont use multiple threads/workers). It seems the crawling was to slow, result was that only 1 record was everytime in the queue, thus the multiple dfps wasnt faster than the router. Our question is: Overhead of the ActiveMQ (can it be tested with persistence and without?) Add some performance counters for bandwith if needed.  [reply] Comment 1 Ivan Churkin 2008-11-20 05:01:28 EST (In reply to comment #0) Basically I do not understand the problem...  It is obvious that one DFP will be faster.  Reasons:  Guess 2 nodes was started on one computer :) (limited resources). The main reason that processing is not resource consuming now. It is too fast :). It's easier and faster to process record immediately than to persist message to MQ and process it later.  Crawling -> mainly HDD load Persisting into JMS -> mainly HDD load Processing -> mainly CPU load  There is no one reason to make delayed processing is processing is fast. There is no reasons to persist messages into in the same node where file-crawling executed.  [reply] Comment 2 Sebastian Voigt 2008-11-24 05:02:32 EST Beside that the use case is not appropiate for clustering tests, we are interested about where bottlenecks could be: therefore could you please investigate more in detail: 1) Performance of the Queue a) current Configuration b) could persistence be simple deactivate (queuee should be used of course) c) could you make measurements: with/without persistence vs. no queue 2) Router/Listener Implementation a) connection handling: JMS Connections reopened for every Record? b) Creation of Message/Connection-Objects for every Record? summary: Extend FileSystem Crawler: Gathering NTFS-ACL
description: Extend FileSystem Crawler: Gathering NTFS-ACL [reply] Description Sebastian Voigt 2008-11-23 08:43:22 EST 1) search for solution to crawl also NTFS-ACLs 2) extend existing crawler or write a new crawler (maybe add it as optional) 3) implementation  [reply] Comment 1 Ivan Churkin 2008-12-16 10:47:10 EST mainly acl toolkit (c++ and jni) written and integrated into SMILA (but not commited into trunk) todo: use it in FS crawler  [reply] Comment 2 Sebastian Voigt 2009-01-27 04:50:49 EST Rember: it should be possible to start the FileSystemCrawler without the NTFS-ACL-Things? Could we deploy it without the dll? What happens if a IndexConfiguration is used with Attributes that apply to NTFS-ACLs...  [reply] Comment 3 Ivan Churkin 2009-01-27 09:42:36 EST (In reply to comment #2) > Rember: it should be possible to start the FileSystemCrawler without the > NTFS-ACL-Things?  User may exclude ACL related attributes from index order configuration.   > Could we deploy it without the dll? Yes, simply exclude "org.eclipse.smila.utils.fs.acl.win32" fragment from distribution.  > What happens if a IndexConfiguration is used with Attributes that apply to > NTFS-ACLs... >  It will cause empty ACL attributes added to record.    ACL attributes are optional, it will be calculated when all of the conditions are satisfied:  1. There is ACL related attribute in index order configuration. 2. There is OS specific fragment with native library used to calculate ACL. 3. Library was successfully loaded.  If any of conditions was not satisfied, then no ACL attributes added to record without error thrown etc, only warnings are allowed.    [reply] Comment 4 Ivan Churkin 2009-02-02 10:15:45 EST guess fixed  [reply] Comment 5 Ivan Churkin 2009-02-02 10:16:10 EST guess fixed  [reply] Comment 6 Andreas Weber 2013-04-15 11:33:19 EDT Closing this  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [Xml Storage] Backup & Restore - BDB Xml
description: [Xml Storage] Backup & Restore - BDB Xml [reply] Description Marius Cimpean 2008-11-25 08:55:27 EST Steps To Reproduce: how to do backup/restore of xml data and the gotchas.  think and write about how that could/should be handled in  our case (see my mail on this, i.e. hot vs. cold). the advantages and disadvantages of the diff. approaches. best to have a PoC or branch of trunk for this.  [reply] Comment 1 Marius Cimpean 2008-11-25 09:03:18 EST The BDB Xml backup & restore procedures are available via BDB tools (executable files - Cpp sources that have been transformed in exe files).  From this point of view the backup & restore mechanism can be based on one of the following options: 1. call the exe files with the appropriate parameters (starting new process) Advantages: less effort (already in the sandbox), when upgrading to new versions we only supply the new db tools Disadvantage: not Java code  2. Implement (migrate Cpp classes to Java) for backup & restore - Advantage: Java code control Disadvantage: much more effort for implementation; upgrading to new BDB Xml versions may need re-implementation - changes  So, basically I just want to know your opinion, constraints (if any) about this.  http://forums.oracle.com/forums/thread.jspa?forumID=274&threadID=448577&messageID=3140475#3140475  [reply] Comment 2 Marius Cimpean 2008-11-27 05:06:38 EST The ssandbox contains the org.eclipse.smila.bdbxmltest project where the following functionalities and tests have been implemented and tested: - backup (hotbackup and incremental backup) through the DB tools (db_hotbackup and db_recovery) and API implementation - recovery (normal recovery and catastrophic recovery) through DB tools (db_recovery) and API implementation  The tests use to populate one environment with 4 containers in three different ways (which are relevant for the data integrity when backup&restore while transaction are still being executed).  Following tests are covered: - Hotackup with normal recovery while inserting documents - Hotbackup with normal recovery - Hotbackup with catastrophic recovery - Hotbackup with catastrophic recovery by using the BS tools (programmatically).  [reply] Comment 3 Marius Cimpean 2008-11-27 14:24:47 EST Tested hot_backup and recovery during multiple threads writing into the environment containers with deadlocks-resolving.  Tests succeeded even if hot-backup was done during deadlocks-resolving. The restored environment contained all data that was backed-up till the moment of backup execution.  The recovered data 's integrity is fine - that means all recovered documents are available with the new restored environment.  Tested indexes : - environment with two containers (both containers have been populated with 5000 documents - same content); One environment is indexed by one of the xml element; the other container rhas no index.  After populating the two containers and performing queries (identical query) for both containers the results are in advantage of the indexed container:  XQuery: collection("notIndexedContainer.dbxml")/testDoc[docId="450-0-6"] - took 562 ms ; returned one document  XQuery: collection("indexedContainer.dbxml")/testDoc[docId="450-0-6"] - took 2 ms; returned one document  The population time of the two containers is not relevant (considering that one container is indexed and the other isn't)  [reply] Comment 4 thomas menzel 2009-06-19 08:30:48 EDT closing this as BDX CQ has been revoked  [reply] Comment 5 thomas menzel 2009-06-19 08:30:58 EDT closing this as BDX CQ has been revoked  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

"Content-type: text/html" We can add attribute to MetaAttribute configuration that will allow to configure how headers are returned: 1. as a header line The same structure like it is implemented now 2. return only metadata values In this case meta names will be stripped and only values will be returned: MetaValue1 MetaValue2 ... summary: [Blackboard API] Temporary File Access
description: [Blackboard API] Temporary File Access [reply] Description Sebastian Voigt 2008-12-01 04:57:20 EST We need (especially for the Stellent Pipelet) an java File (Class/Reference) access for Attachments.  That means: Attachments should be accessible with a File Ref: File getAttachmentAsFile(Id, String attachmentName) Blackboard should create a Temporary File and return File for it this temporary Should be automatically deleted, when pipelet has finished the work. This file should not be changeable (if we should really monitor this?). With a special command / flag, the file should be allowed to be changed from the pipelet, and what is more important: the content of this file should be written to the attachment in the blackboard-record. That means pipelets can use this workflow to update attachments and they can work with File-References.  Please make some suggestions regarding the "write"-flag, then implement it  [reply] Comment 1 Juergen Schumacher 2008-12-01 05:17:41 EST I think the main functionality should already be part of the BinStorage API, because BinStorage may be able to use have more efficient methods for providing this file than reading the complete stream into a new temporary file. For example, the current Java-IO based approach could create a file object immediately for the file in the BinStorage without having to copy it. Or dou you think this could problems with write-access to this file? Then maybe still we could use this approach for read-only access and to the copying only when the client requests write access.  This means the BinStorage API would be enhanced by methods like - File getFileAccess(String id, boolean write) - void releaseFile(String id)  and the Blackboard would use these methods and add the necessary synchronization with the record instance on the blackboard.  [reply] Comment 2 Dmitry Hazin 2008-12-01 06:25:08 EST I think it should be ok to use BinStorage functionality with current implementation. But further if BinStorage will be remote service, getting File from BinStorage will make no sence.  [reply] Comment 3 Sebastian Voigt 2008-12-01 06:40:39 EST Yes, in the case that we use remote communication with the binstorage we can create a local copy when we read the attachments (have to read it). I've discussed it a little bit with georg (in more detail): we think we should have two methods beside the existing api: File getAttachmentAsFile(id, attachmentName): would read it (like getasInputStream) from the binstorage and create a local copy (we should discuss if the getAsInputstream also create a local copy every time --> that means we try to cache the attachments like we do it with the record (is not implemented by now).  setAttachmentAsFile(id, attachmentName, File) The Pipelet user can sent a file as attachment to the record. Two use cases: use it with a File that was retrieved with get...AsFile(): 1) User has worked (changed) with the local File and want to inform the Blackboard about it. 2) User wants to add self created file to record The Set..AsFile-method makes the talk about the flag/command about changed local files obsolet.   the temporary files should only be deleted after the end of the pipeline (not after each pipelet), or when the local file isnt used anymore ( File A1 = getAsFile(); setAsFile(..., A2)--> temporary file of A1 can be deleted). Blackboard has to monitor the local temporary files and the reference to the attachments.  [reply] Comment 4 Dmitry Hazin 2008-12-03 12:06:00 EST If BinStorage API would be enhanced by methods like - File getFileAccess(String id, boolean write) - void releaseFile(String id) does this mean that they should be implemented for all present binstorage BinaryPersistence implementations? This method will become obsolete with remote binstorage service, so should it really be implemented for all implementations?  [reply] Comment 5 Dmitry Hazin 2008-12-12 08:07:38 EST Added two methods: getAttachmentAsFile: creates copy of the attachment into local temporary file and returns File object; setAttachmentFromFile: saves attachment from file to BinaryStorage.  Temporary files are removed when record is committed (Probably also remove all temp files on blackboard activation/deactivation?).  [reply] Comment 6 Andreas Weber 2013-04-15 11:34:04 EDT Closing this  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [tml][core] Use Jars
description: [tml][core] Use Jars [reply] Description Bjorn Freeman-Benson 2008-12-02 18:55:32 EST +++ This bug was initially created as a clone of Bug #252800 +++  Projects must use jar'ed plug-ins (with unpack=false) unless authorized by the planning council for technical reasons. Nested jars should be avoided if possible since it creates problems for projects that has dependencies to such plug-ins. The OSGi runtime is fine with it but the compiler is not able to handle classpaths that contain nested jars. In case only one nested jar exists, it is often better to expand the contents of that jar into the root folder (i.e. unnest the jar). If a plug-in contains large files that are frequently used (opened and closed), a jar'ed plug-in might degrade performance significantly since the file must be decompressed each time it is opened.  [reply] Comment 1 Eric Cloninger 2008-12-10 12:21:15 EST All TmL plugins satisfy this requirement.  [reply] Comment 2 Fabio Fantato 2008-12-11 15:46:46 EST *** Bug 251077 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [Crawler] Adopt Crawlers to new Crawler API
description: [Crawler] Adopt Crawlers to new Crawler API [reply] Description Sebastian Voigt 2008-12-22 11:17:13 EST Hi Dmitry,  we have developed a new Crawler API, but is still in negotation.  But we need feedback, thus could you please adopt file and web-crawler to this new api and give us feedback: - personal opionion - advantages/Disadvantages from the view of a crawler developer - api understandable?  the new crawler api is stored in the sandbox, please copy bundles to that place also, if you have to change them (obviously the crawler bundles). dont change code in the svn-trunk please  [reply] Comment 1 Dmitry Hazin 2009-01-26 05:04:10 EST Adopted crawlers code is in the sandbox. Here is my feedback: New crawler api is a bit simpler for crawler developer then previous version but isn't too much different. New api is more clear for crawler developer in case that he doesn't need to handle the DI list and getRecord(int pos) method, returning record by Id is much more clear. Also it's good that hash is now calculated inside the crawler by use of DataReferenceFactory. However new api has some new weaknesses. In the previous version crawler developer had first to prepare MObject containing DI data and then the actual record. With new API DataReference replaced MObject containing di data and to construct DataReference object developer must call factory method with id attributes, hash attributes and attachments parameters. The problem is that there is no handy container class for DataReferenceFactory parameters (it was MObject in previous implementation). For example, when adopting crawlers, I used Record object to keep parameters that were needed for DataReference creation, but I still had to implement functions that separate atrributes to id, hash and attachments attributes. Another difficulty for the crawler developer (not directly related to new api) is that he must be aware of differences between record attributes and record attachments, treat them differently and serialize attachments to byte[] every time.  [reply] Comment 2 Dmitry Hazin 2009-01-29 05:54:01 EST fixed  [reply] Comment 3 Andreas Weber 2013-04-15 11:41:23 EDT Closing this  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [fiximprove]: Preprocessing hooks are broken in Eclipse 3.5
description: [fiximprove]: Preprocessing hooks are broken in Eclipse 3.5 [reply] Description Craig Setera 2009-01-18 21:46:00 EST Because of the Equinox refactoring done as part of https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=246132 , the Equinox hooks that are installed to support preprocessing are broken in Eclipse 3.5.  This results in an exception of the form:  Caused by: java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: org/eclipse/osgi/framework/internal/core/BundleLoader at org.eclipse.mtj.core.hooks.MTJClassLoadingHook.createClassLoader(Unknown Source) at org.eclipse.osgi.baseadaptor.BaseData.createClassLoader(BaseData.java:92) at org.eclipse.osgi.internal.loader.BundleLoader.createBCL(BundleLoader.java:821)  While the hope is to move to the new JDT extension point for handling preprocessing, it would be worthwhile for the current hooks to work just in case.  [reply] Comment 1 Craig Setera 2009-01-18 21:48:56 EST Fixed on trunk.  The createClassLoader method of the MTJClassLoadingHook class was altered to use Java reflection to locate the method to be called.  This allows the code to avoid directly referencing the BundleLoader class that was refactored in Eclipse 3.5.  The resulting code works in both Eclipse 3.4 and 3.5.  [reply] Comment 2 Gustavo de Paula 2009-07-09 09:58:28 EDT released on MTJ 1.0  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

[reply] Comment 10 Peter Wissel 2009-02-03 07:05:19 EST Created attachment 124533 [details] smila-log of flashseite.com  [reply] Comment 11 Dmitry Hazin 2009-02-03 09:52:13 EST (In reply to comment #9) > (In reply to comment #6) > > (In reply to comment #0) > > > After testing SWFParser again, the content of the indexed site > > > http://www.flashseite.com/ is still the site's title and not the expected html > > > source code. > > > > > > > It's an expected behavior, content is a result of invoking of HtmlToTextPipelet > > before adding record to the index. > > > > If this behavior is expected why the HtmlToTextPipelet is invoked only in two > test situation (＾http://fotolima.flashseite.com/＾ and > ?http://www.flashseite.com/＾)? If I crawl ?http://www.2advanced.com/＾ the > content in the index matches with the source-code the browser shows. If this is > intentional behavior than what is the reason for executing  HtmlToTextPipelet > in the cases ＾http://fotolima.flashseite.com/＾ and ?http://www.flashseite.com/＾ > but not in the case ?http://www.2advanced.com/＾? > >  Rule for mime-type in addpipeline is the following:  <!-- extract txt from html files --> <if name="conditionIsHtml"> <condition>($request.records/rec:Record[1]/rec:A[@n="MimeType"]/rec:L/rec:V = "text/html") or ($request.records/rec:Record[1]/rec:A[@n="MimeType"]/rec:L/rec:V = "text/xml")</condition>  MimeType attribute is currently set by webcrawler based on Content-Type http header; for http://www.2advanced.com/ it's "text/html; charset=UTF-8" So it doesn't match this rule hence HtmlToTextPipelet isn't executed.     > > (In reply to comment #2) > > > There are some other topics to talk about. > > > > > > 1) After crawling I open the lucene index an look up the summary of test_index > > > with luke (http://www.getopt.org/luke/). There is one document (record) in the > > > index and one deletion. Why the same record (http://www.flashseite.com/) is > > > crawled two times? > > > > I think it was caused resolved problem of DI didn't save it's state when smila > > was closed. I crawled the same url several times before stopping smila, then > > stopped, started again and crawled again. Records were correctly skipped as > > unchanged hence there were no deletions into index. > > > > Problem is that SMILA wasn¨t closed. I download the actual build (1050) and use > default configuration. I only change the seed-tag in web-crawler-configuration > to ?http://www.flashseite.com/＾. I crawl one time and in the index is one > deletion and one document. I will post the log to show, that the same record is > crawled two times (smila-log-flashseite.com.txt). >  The reason is that crawler fetches url http://www.flashseite.com/sendmail.php that redirects back to http://www.flashseite.com/ so it returns already crawled record. It seems that if previous copy of this record  is not yet committed to index, DI manager treats it as new, hence it's added twice. I'll fix webcrawler so that  when redirecting to new url it will check that this url wasn't already crawled  [reply] Comment 12 Andreas Weber 2013-04-15 11:35:49 EDT Closing this  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

confirm this.  What i am just wondering about, it seems that the storing mechansim isnt working when the user only close the "smila-"window. I know that peter has the effect, that after he has restarted smila ( i dont know how he closed it) the deltaindexing information was lost...  [reply] Comment 2 Dmitry Hazin 2009-01-29 05:57:58 EST (In reply to comment #1) > i can confirm this. > > What i am just wondering about, it seems that the storing mechansim isnt > working when the user only close the "smila-"window. > I know that peter has the effect, that after he has restarted smila ( i dont > know how he closed it) the deltaindexing information was lost... >  I think when user closes smila window, no shutdown actions are executed at all. The same happens if user will close application with "exit" command. Here is a quote from osgi commands help: shutdown - shutdown the OSGi Framework close - shutdown and exit exit - exit immediately (System.exit)  [reply] Comment 3 Sebastian Voigt 2009-01-30 10:10:03 EST yes, closing the smila window results in no shutdown  [reply] Comment 4 Ivan Churkin 2009-02-02 04:42:43 EST Delta indexing manager load its state when service started and stores state when service stopped. Without correct shutdown procedure called, state will not be stored.  Moreover, it was found a new bug with Declarative Services (DS) shutdown procedure in Eclipse platform. When complete shutdown occurs, Platform unloads bundle reference faster before DS executes deactivate(final ComponentContext context). The result is, when we searching the bundle in the deactivate() procedure, no bundle found => no workspace folder found.  I avoided it by storing bundle reference inside the service and extending WorkspaceHelper API to accept bundle.  [reply] Comment 5 Ivan Churkin 2009-02-02 10:14:43 EST guess fixed  [reply] Comment 6 Andreas Weber 2013-04-15 11:36:16 EDT Closing this  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: Support docshare in certain multi-page editors
description: Support docshare in certain multi-page editors [reply] Description Nitin Dahyabhai 2009-02-03 14:05:23 EST Created attachment 124590 [details] patch  3.0.0.v20090127-1900  DocShare collaboration is terrific, but it's limited to ITextEditor parts.  One idiom that we've adopted in WTP, and our adopter product, is to allow a mutli-page editor which doesn't implement ITextEditor itself to return ITextEditor as an adapter, providing access to its source page (assuming it only has one such page, we never worked out the semantics beyond that).  Most of the time this is the actual editor part embedded as the source page, providing a straightforward way to enable support in editors like WTP's XML Editor.  I intend to add docshare to the WTP Source Editing M6 plan, but it would be a shame for our multi-page editors to not support this properly.  Patch attached adding the various calls in the DocShare plug-in to make use of this pattern, and remove an unnecessary restriction on its use with IFileEditorInput.  [reply] Comment 1 Marcelo Mayworm 2009-02-05 17:29:35 EST Thanks Nitin.  Scott, Mustafa and Nitin, I'm going to take a look at the patch...I will send comments here late.  [reply] Comment 2 Marcelo Mayworm 2009-02-09 19:07:42 EST The patch was applied, tested, and committed to HEAD.  Thanks Nitin for the contribution.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: NullPointerException in FileSystemCrawler when renaming Path attribute
description: NullPointerException in FileSystemCrawler when renaming Path attribute [reply] Description Andreas Weber 2009-02-17 10:06:30 EST Created attachment 125893 [details] FileSystemCrawler patch  I think there is a bug in the FileSystemCrawler.  In my crawler configuration I renamed the "Path" attribute, e.g. ... <Attribute Type="String" Name="MyPath" KeyAttribute="true"> <FileAttributes>Path</FileAttributes> </Attribute> ... and got a NullPointerException in the FileSystemCrawler (line 312):  File file = new File(diData.getAttribute(FileAttributesType.PATH.value()).getLiteral().getStringValue());  This is reproducable.  I had a deeper look at it, and think I can provide a fix:  Instead of reading the path attribute with the hardcoded FileAttributesType.PATH, one has to find and use the configured path attribute name. So the line above could be replaced like that:  final String pathAttributeName = getPathAttributeName(); final File file = new File(diData.getAttribute(pathAttributeName).getLiteral().getStringValue());  private String getPathAttributeName() { for (Attribute a : _attributes) { if (a.getFileAttributes().equals(FileAttributesType.PATH)) { return a.getName(); } } return null; }  Find attached the patched FileSystemCrawler class.  [reply] Comment 1 Ivan Churkin 2009-02-20 08:22:34 EST Hi Andreas, Many thanks for that issue. SMILA repository have been updated.  [reply] Comment 2 Andreas Weber 2013-04-15 11:37:07 EDT Closing this  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

I know that there have been issues with using the RichTextEditor within dialogs in the past.  Perhaps there is still some quirk of event firing in the RichTextEditor when being used in this fashion?   More information:  [reply] Comment 1 Bingxue Xu 2009-02-20 16:25:33 EST Please investigate this one. [reply] Comment 39 Xiao Dan Xia 2010-01-05 10:07:27 EST I tried my test plugin on eclipse 3.3.2 and eclipse 3.5.0. On eclipse 3.3.2, modify event can be received and text can be correctly retrieved. On eclipse 3.5.0, I can't get modify event as well as keyReleased event(I can get keyPressed event). So, it should be a SWT problem. Can you try your plugin on eclipse3.3.2? BTW, there's already a bug against SWT(https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=280146) to track keyUp issue. You may add comments and discussion there.  [reply] Comment 40 Flavio Donze 2010-01-06 07:39:41 EST I've tested my test plug-in with eclipse 3.2.2 and I do get the ModifyEvents and keyPressed.  As mentioned above I have done some hacking in the passed (July 2009) on the rte.js file. Afterwards I did get ModifyEvents using eclipse 3.5.1 but still having a strange behavior. see the following link for details: http://www.eclipse.org/forums/index.php?t=tree&th=16670&S=28cf035914bb5b2b73482ea57f1ed6c8#page_top  I actually "don't care" about the KeyEvents, I would rather get the modify events for my databinding. Maybe fixing the rte.js file would solve the issue?  [reply] Comment 41 Xiao Dan Xia 2010-01-07 05:00:09 EST For your case, as a workaround, you can try move your change to function keyReleased() and attach keyrelease event to this function. Refer to following code fragment.  function enableRichTextEditing(html) { ...  if ("attachEvent" in doc) { doc.attachEvent("onkeyup", keyReleased); .... } if ("addEventListener" in doc) { doc.addEventListener("keypress", keyPressed, true); doc.addEventListener("keyrelease", keyReleased, true); ... }   function keyReleased(event) { var keyCode = event.keyCode; if (keyCode == 0 && !document.all) { keyCode = event.charCode; switch (keyCode) { case 98: keyCode = KEY_B; break; case 99: keyCode = KEY_C; break; case 102: keyCode = KEY_F; break; case 105: keyCode = KEY_I; break; case 115: keyCode = KEY_S; break; case 117: keyCode = KEY_U; break; case 118: keyCode = KEY_V; break; case 120: keyCode = KEY_X; break; case 122: keyCode = KEY_Z; break; } } var ctrlKey = event.ctrlKey; var shiftKey = event.shiftKey; var altKey = event.altKey;  if ( !ctrlKey && !altKey ) { var modified = true; for (var i = 0; i < excludeModify.length; i++ ) { if ( keyCode == excludeModify[i] ) { modified = false; } } if ( modified == true ) { setTimeout("setStatus(STATUS_MODIFIED, null);", 10); } } }  [reply] Comment 42 Flavio Donze 2010-01-07 11:18:01 EST Thanks a lot. I do now get my desired ModifyEvents. Also when CTRL or ALT is pressed but that doesn't matter I can handle this in my listener.  But shouldn't this issue be reopened since there are still problems around?  greets and thanks again!  [reply] Comment 43 Nikolas Falco 2010-07-28 08:36:00 EDT I run test posted by Jeff Hardy using an addKeyListener(KeyAdapter) instead addListener on eclipse 3.6, every time i press a key, console log correctly. So SWT browser widget haven't problem to catch key event.  Running test post by Flavio Donz└ that already use addKeyListenet(KeyAdapter), listener is waked up only on backspace, canc or enter was. Instead key listener never print to console "keyPressed..." message.  [reply] Comment 44 Nikolas Falco 2010-07-28 08:37:53 EDT I run on Windows XP SP3 My browser are: Internet Explorer 8.0.6001.18702 Firefox 3.6.8  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: RichText's getData always returns null
description: RichText's getData always returns null [reply] Description Andreas Hagerer 2009-02-27 11:16:13 EST The method getData in RichText as well as in RichTextEditor always returns null:  public Object getData(String key) { if (richText != null) { richText.getData(key); } return null; }  Kind regards Andreas  [reply] Comment 1 Bingxue Xu 2009-02-27 12:03:29 EST I believe that you have to extend the RTE feature in your own code to implement this method.  Please review how EPF Composer use the RTE feature in its source code so you can use the similar way to extend and use it.  [reply] Comment 2 Andreas Hagerer 2009-03-02 04:19:23 EST (In reply to comment #1) > I believe that you have to extend the RTE feature in your own code to implement > this method. > > Please review how EPF Composer use the RTE feature in its source code so you > can use the similar way to extend and use it. >  I used MethodRichText in org.eclipse.epf.authoring.ui.editors as an example. As far as I tested it, it works after modifying the method getData in RichText to public Object getData(String key) { if (richText != null) { return richText.getData(key); } return null; }  I puzzled about the intention of the if-statment in which the return is missing.  Bye Andreas  [reply] Comment 3 Bingxue Xu 2009-03-02 13:54:56 EST Dancy, please review this. Thanks.  [reply] Comment 4 Xiao Dan Xia 2009-03-03 04:39:13 EST yes, it's a bug. "return" is missed both in RichText and RichTextEditor. Will fix it soon.  [reply] Comment 5 Andreas Hagerer 2009-03-03 06:05:09 EST (In reply to comment #4)  May I add another observation?  In RichText access to methods of its attribute editor is performed in most cases under condition that the editor-attribute is not null, e.g. public void removeKeyListener(KeyListener listener) { if (editor != null) { editor.removeKeyListener(listener); } }  But there are still some RichText-methods (e.g. isDisposed, addStatusTextListener) which access an editor's method without checking that editor is not null.  A similar observation is made concerning the attribute richText in class RichTextEditor (e.g. checkModify, getSelected).  Bye Andreas  [reply] Comment 6 Xiao Dan Xia 2009-03-03 20:14:36 EST This observation is valid, however it does not seem to cause any problems. If it does, please file another bug. Thanks.  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments

summary: [EWM] Add logging support to the EMF workflow model
description: [EWM] Add logging support to the EMF workflow model [reply] Description Bryan Hunt 2009-03-25 11:58:31 EDT During my talk on the EMF workflow model, it was suggested to add logging capabilities to the workflow model.  This bug will track any ideas on the best way to do this.  [reply] Comment 1 Eike Stepper 2009-03-25 16:40:20 EDT In a similar effort I worked on in the past I added some logging API to the workflow execution context that gets passed into all the lifecycle methods (do you have component lifecycle??) andinto the run() methods of the components. That turned out to be very convenient because the framework can create/maintain the logger instances and associate them with the target components.  As a related matter (might need a separate bugzilla) I added API to the execution context that can be used by the lifecycle/run methods to report cross reference information towards the framework. The framework can use this information in subsequent executions to more intelligently determine the set of components that need re-execution. Maybe this is only applicable to code generator workflows. I used it to optimize re-generation of artifacts based on particular model changes.  [reply] Comment 2 Miles Parker 2009-04-01 23:04:57 EDT Hi guys,  I've actually spent quite a bit of time implementing this -- at least I think we're talking about the same thing. This is stuff I built for the generators for my MetaABM project so would be (assuming all goes well) part of the Eclipse AMP project eventually.  Haven't yet made the leap to MWE so these are all based on oAW Workflow.  It all work quite well. The current basic user story is..  1. User invokes builder. (This could easily be generalized to any workflow invocation.) 2. Generator executes. 3. On completion: a) if workflow error(s) occurred: present to user and log. (All errors are stored and placed in multi-status list so only one error reported per workflow invoke at workflow termination == No spamming error log. :) ) b) if warnings occurred, log. (Again, one multi per workflow.) c) otherwise, log an info for successful completion. 4. Traps RuntimeExceptions that occur during generator invocation and reports them as errors in 3.  But wait, there's more..  4. On .chk error or warning: Creates markers from invoked Workflow object for the producing EObject in the EMF editor. Users can then double-click on problem markers and EMF editor object is selected just as with validation errors.  and..  5. An extendible builder for arbitrary workflows on all models instances of a provided ecore model within a project.  6. Generic handlers for invoking workflows using the builder. Users simply have to override the ResourceJobHandler#execute with a call to the appropriate builder, and register the handler extension.  I'm attaching a few classes. They aren't perfect, my lack of documentation is embarrassing. ;) There also need to be generalized, obviously. See note for LogOAW.. will have issues in the (unlikely?) case of parallel generation.  My eventual plan was to provide an extension point for all of this so that plugin developers would only have to provide a workflow reference and an ecore extension to provide a custom workflow builder.  If MWE team think it is worth polishing up (as I make the transition) then let me know and I'll do that. (I hold copyright and can release as ECL, but don't (yet?!) have committer status.)  Here is what is going on in the classes:  AbstractOAWBuilder -- manages all aspects of build process, including logging, reporting and markers LogOAW -- collects workflow log issues as they occur. OAWUIExceptionHandler -- intercepts workflow caused RTE for log.  ModelMarkerHelper -- support for supplying workflow objects with problem markers.  ResourceHandler, ResourceJobHandler -- Handler support for invoking the builder manually on single resource.  GenerateInterfaceHandler -- example of usage of above  To make ModelMarkers work, you'd need to edit generated EMF Editor as in the below..  /** * <!-- begin-user-doc --> <!-- end-user-doc --> * * @generated NOT */ public void gotoMarker(IMarker marker) { try { if (marker.getType().equals(EValidator.MARKER)) { String uriAttribute = marker.getAttribute(EValidator.URI_ATTRIBUTE, null); if (uriAttribute != null) { URI uri = URI.createURI(uriAttribute); EObject eObject = editingDomain.getResourceSet().getEObject(uri, true); if (eObject != null) { setSelectionToViewer(Collections.singleton(editingDomain.getWrapper(eObject))); } } } else if (marker.getType().equals(ModelMarkerHelper.MARKER_ID)) { String elementPath = marker.getAttribute(ModelMarkerHelper.MARKER_ELEMENT, null); URI uri = URI.createURI(elementPath); EObject eObject = editingDomain.getResourceSet().getEObject(uri, true); if (eObject != null) { setSelectionToViewer(Collections.singleton(editingDomain.getWrapper(eObject))); } else { StatusManager.getManager().handle( new Status(Status.WARNING, "org.metaabm.ide", "Couldn't locate: " + uri)); } } } catch (CoreException exception) { MetaModelerPlugin.INSTANCE.log(exception); } }   [reply] Comment 3 Miles Parker 2009-04-01 23:08:39 EDT Created attachment 130646 [details] oAW Logging Implementation  [reply] Comment 4 Miles Parker 2009-04-01 23:10:16 EDT For further context, see:  http://svn.metascapeabm.com/metaabm/org.metaabm.ide/src/org/metaabm/ide/  [I really need to factor this stuff out!]  [reply] Comment 5 Bryan Hunt 2009-04-02 00:06:58 EDT Based on the comments so far, here's what I'm thinking:  Create a Log class that holds logging information for a WorkflowUnitOfWork and store instances of the Log in the WorkflowContext mapped with the instance of WorkflowUnitOfWork as the key just like the state information.  public class WorkflowLog { public Collection getAll(); public Collection getErrors(); public Collection getWarnings(); public Collection getInfos();  public void log(...); // Not sure of the parameters, but want to avoid IStatus }  An example of it's use:  public class MyTask extends WorkflowUnitOfWork { protected void run(WorkflowContext context) { Log log = getLog(context); log.log(LogLevel.INFO, "Starting execution"); } }  [reply] Comment 6 Bryan Hunt 2009-04-02 00:12:52 EDT (In reply to comment #1) > workflow execution context that gets passed into all the lifecycle methods (do > you have component lifecycle??) andinto the run() methods of the components.  I do not have component lfecycle methods.  I do keep the component state, which is related to the lifecycle of the component in the WorkflowContext.  I could not think of a compelling usecase for lifecycle methods.  If you need to do any processing before or after the run method, why not just add a task.  If anyone has a usecase, please open a new Bugzilla to discuss.  [reply] Comment 7 Miles Parker 2009-04-02 13:57:15 EDT Bryan, ok, on reflection it looks like my proposed contribution was way over scope. I'm not sure how much MWE is planning to be involved in more UI oriented stuff, but would like to discuss this in more detail. See my EMFT newsgroup reply to you.  [reply] Comment 8 Bryan Hunt 2009-04-10 01:45:22 EDT I've added logging support to the workflow model.  Logs are stored per WorkflowComponent in the WorkflowContext.  The logs may be cleared by calling resetLog() on the context.  [reply] Comment 9 Bernd Kolb 2009-05-27 10:28:47 EDT closing  Add Comment  Collapse All Comments Expand All Comments
